    Why Are the Majority of Active Compounds in the CNS Domain Natural Products? A Critical Analysis

    • Sonali S. Bharate
      Sonali S. Bharate
      Preformulation Laboratory, PK−PD Toxicology and Formulation Division, CSIR—Indian Institute of Integrative Medicine, Canal Road, Jammu 180001, India
      More by Sonali S. Bharate
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0001-7267-5080
      • , 
    • Serge Mignani
      Serge Mignani
      UMR 860, Laboratoire de Chimie et de Biochimie Pharmacologiques et Toxicologique, Université Paris Descartes, PRES Sorbonne Paris Cité, CNRS, 45 rue des Saints Pères, 75006 Paris, France
      CQM—Centro de Química da Madeira, MMRG, Universidade da Madeira, Campus da Penteada, 9020-105 Funchal, Portugal
      Medicinal Chemistry Division, CSIR—Indian Institute of Integrative Medicine, Canal Road, Jammu 180001, India
      More by Serge Mignani
      View Biography
      • , and

      Ram A. Vishwakarma
      Medicinal Chemistry Division, CSIR—Indian Institute of Integrative Medicine, Canal Road, Jammu 180001, India
      *Phone: +91-191-2585006-13. Fax: +91-191-2586333 E-mail: [email protected]

    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2018, 61, 23, 10345–10374

    SUBJECTS:
    • Amines,

    • Receptors
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Small-molecule natural products (NPs) have a long and successful track record of providing first-in-class drugs and pharmacophore (scaffolds) in all therapeutic areas, serving as a bridge between modern and traditional medicine. This trajectory has been remarkably successful in three key areas of modern therapeutics: cancers, infections, and CNS diseases. Beginning with the discovery of morphine 200 years ago, natural products have remained the primary source of new drugs/scaffolds for CNS diseases. In this perspective, we address the question: why are the majority of active compounds in the CNS domain natural products? Our analysis indicates that ∼84% approved drugs for CNS diseases are NPs or NP-inspired, and interestingly, 20 natural products provided more than 400 clinically approved CNS drugs. We have discussed unique physicochemical properties of NPs and NP-inspired vis-à-vis synthetic drugs, isoform selectivity, and evolutionary relationship, providing a rationale for increasing focus on natural product driven discovery for next-generation drugs for neurodegenerative diseases.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Modern medicine has deep roots in the ancient and indigenous systems of medicine practiced worldwide for centuries,(1,2) and the results of this symbiosis are truly remarkable, as over 50% of the currently used drugs and pharmacophores are small-molecule natural products (NPs) derived directly or inspired from the plant and microbial species.(3−5) From a quick analysis of the history of modern medicine (USFDA Orange Book), it becomes obvious(6) that most of the “first-in-class” drugs and pharmacophores [anticancer, antibiotics, antimalarials, antidiabetic, immunosuppressant, blood-pressure and cholesterol lowering, and the central nervous system (CNS) drugs] were discovered(7) from NPs (microbes and medicinal plants), many of them with recorded use as traditional medicine for hundreds of years. If one tracks the scientific threads of the discovery of most of the magic bullets such as morphine, ephedrine, reserpine, quinine, camptothecin, vincristine, colchicine, podophyllotoxin, artemisinin, ivermectin, taxol, aspirin, and many more), the root of discovery invariably leads to a traditional system of medicine (Indian, Chinese, African, or South American) or longstanding empirical observations by the tribal populations. During the drug development process, the initial NP leads were invariably modified(8−10) by medicinal chemistry to achieve desired PK profile, efficacy, and safety. Perhaps one of the best example of this lineage of modern medicine with biodiversity is the NP lovastatin isolated from the fungus Aspergillus terreus in Japan as a potent HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor, followed by the development of a blockbuster cholesterol-lowering drug atorvastatin (Lipitor). In addition to providing life-saving drugs, natural products also provided(11) inspiration and impetus for much of the advances in synthetic organic chemistry, biosynthesis, and cell biology in last hundred years.
    This glorious journey began with the isolation(12,13) of the first pure natural product morphine from the opium poppy (Papaver somniferum) by Friedrich Serturner in 1805 and its commercialization by Merck in 1826 as a pain medication. Since then, it has been a unique trajectory of the partnership between chemistry and pharmacology with a rich harvest of a large number of therapeutic drugs and cell biology probes from natural products. Historically, natural products have provided drugs for almost all human diseases. However, three disease areas have been particularly benefited from natural products: cancers, bacterial and parasitic infections, and CNS diseases, where a large number of currently used drugs are of natural origin. This situation is even more remarkable(14) for CNS diseases where a majority of the therapeutic agents are natural products, their derivatives, and synthetically designed analogues based on the original NP scaffold.
    In this Perspective, we have addressed the central question as to why the majority of active compounds in the CNS domain are natural products and what is the special evolutionary relationship between natural products and the human brain. Our analysis indicates that ∼84% approved drugs for CNS diseases are natural products (NP) or NP-inspired, and interestingly, 20 such natural products provided more than 400 approved drugs for CNS diseases. The CNS and neurodegenerative diseases result due to the progressive deterioration of the normal structure and function of neurons in the CNS. This cluster of chronic illnesses, many of them age-related, includes neuropathic pain, depression, epilepsy, migraine, schizophrenia, anxiety, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), dementia, Alzheimer’s disease (AD), Parkinson’s disease (PD), Huntington’s disease (HD), and Batten disease (BD). The complexity of CNS diseases and scientific challenges, such as lack of clarity of disease etiology, inadequacy in animal models, is the biggest challenge to pharmaceutical industry and academic research communities.
    In this Perspective, we have analyzed how and why NPs and NP-inspired first-in-class drugs have dominated over synthetic drugs in the CNS domain. From 1940 onward, the USFDA-approved ∼1711 new molecular entities (NMEs) and ∼25% of these are currently being used as CNS therapeutics. These numbers clearly indicate that, along with anti-infective and anticancer agents, the CNS drugs constitute a major share of therapeutics. If we analyze CNS drugs closely, as discussed in the first part of this Perspective, NPs and NP-inspired drugs predominate over synthetic drugs as much as that of the relative proportion of NP/NP-inspired drugs to synthetic drugs in the CNS domain is ∼85% to ∼15%. The dominance of NP/NP-inspired drugs is established from the fact that most of the CNS drugs are either isolated directly from the medicinal plants or fungus species or prepared by modification of NP scaffold or have emerged from simplification of NP structure through medicinal chemistry. Interestingly, the natural products chemistry coupled with the medicinal chemistry of 20 such privileged natural products have led to around 400 drugs approved in various regulatory markets. These CNS agents include hallucinogens, stimulants, analgesics, muscle relaxants, sedative hypnotics, antidepressants, anxiolytics, antipsychotics, anti-Alzheimer’s drugs, anticonvulsants, and antiepileptics targeting different neurotransmitters such as acetylcholine, adenosine, dopamine, GABA, glutamic acid, norepinephrine, and serotonin.
    To address the central point of this Perspective, we have first discussed the chronology of the discovery of key CNS active natural products, medicinal chemistry of the most privileged NP scaffolds leading to a large number of marketed drugs, and their comparison with the CNS drugs of purely synthetic origin. This is followed by the discussion on the CNS drug targets involved in the pharmacology of NP scaffolds and their lineage from the traditional systems of medicine practiced worldwide. Finally, we present the current level of understanding on what makes these CNS active natural products so special; their drug-like and lead-like physicochemical properties, BBB transport, isoform selectivity, their place in the evolutionary scale of things, and the prevailing hypotheses on their special role in species–species interaction and mutually assisted survival.
    The most privileged NP scaffolds isolated in last 200 years, along with their year of discovery and the pharmacological activities, have been compiled in the chronological order in the following Table 1.
    Table 1. Privileged NP Scaffolds among CNS Drugs(12,15−)()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()()(82)
    The drugs and literature were searched by using various databases like The DrugBank (https://www.drugbank.ca/), : Current Index of Medical Specialties (CIMS, https://www.mims.com/india), Wikipedia (https://www.wikipedia.org/), and the Dictionary of Natural Products and Google Scholar. Each of these privileged natural products represents a landmark in the history of the modern drug discovery, which has served as a backbone for the design of many synthetic drugs in the CNS domain. The lineage of subsequent discovery of several first-in-class and best-in-class drugs from each NP scaffold is discussed in the following sections.

    2. NPs and NP-Inspired Medicines in the CNS Domain

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    For many decades, NP scaffolds have served as a source of drugs for treating CNS disorders. The structural diversity of NPs has provided different classes of drugs, with huge diversity in the mechanisms by which they work. The important classes of CNS-active NPs and the drugs that are either NP derivatives or NP-inspired are discussed as follows.

    Morphine Scaffold

    Morphine (1) is a complex molecule and the first active principle compound from which different analogues have been prepared by modification of one or more of its functional groups.(83) Modification or removal of the 6-hydroxy group in this opioid pharmacophore resulted into drugs, viz. pholcodine (32) and 6-monoacetylmorphine (33), which retained similar analgesic activity to morphine. However, 3-hydroxy substitution, forming, for instance, codeine (6) and ethylmorphine (31), resulted into a reduced analgesic effect compared to morphine. Substitution of the original tertiary-N group with a secondary NH group, as in normorphine (34), resulted in reduced analgesic activity. The reason for this is the high polarity of secondary-NH over tertiary-N groups, which directly affects BBB permeability and thus decreases the activity. Replacing the N-methyl group with allyl or cyclopropylmethyl substitution yielded several drugs, viz. nalorphine (30), naloxone (41), nalmefene (43), and naltrexone (48), which, however, lose analgesic activity. Moreover, they act as antagonists to morphine, as they bind more tightly to the μ-opioid receptor and block morphine from binding. Therefore, these drugs are used as antidotes for the treatment of morphine addiction. Dihydro derivatives of morphine have also been developed and investigated simultaneously for their superiority over morphine as analgesics. These structural modifications yielded 14 drugs, as depicted in Figure 1. Morphine is a polar, addictive molecule and is poorly absorbed upon oral administration due to high (≈90%) hepatic metabolism. These problems associated with morphine motivated the discovery of morphinan, followed by tricyclic benzomorphan.(84) These simplified opioid scaffolds were discovered with the objective of retaining analgesic activity upon oral administration. The simplification was performed to enable the easy synthesis of analogues with reduced side effects compared to morphine. Removal of ring E gave a series of tetracyclic drugs called morphinans (Figure 1). Morphinans are more potent and long-acting but are more toxic than morphine. The benefit of removing ring E from morphine is that it yields in more lipophilic compounds which favor BBB permeation, e.g., levallorphan (49) and levorphanol (50). The lipophilic nature of these drugs is responsible for their extensive distribution throughout the body, leading to a longer elimination half-life than morphine. The simplification of morphinan by removing rings C and E gave “tricyclic benzomorphan” compounds. This class of compounds proved to possess a lower risk of addiction with reasonable analgesic activity. The search for a nonaddictive benzomorphan yielded six drugs, depicted in Figure 1. Phenazocine (55) was the first benzomorphan to be used clinically. It is highly lipophilic in nature compared with morphine and is well-absorbed upon oral administration.(83) The next generation of analgesics from the opioid motif was discovered by removing rings B, C, and E. These series of compounds are known as 4-phenylpiperidines and 4-anilinopiperidines, which are easier to synthesize in comparison with the previous generations of the opiate scaffold. Piperidine analgesics are fast acting and possess a shorter duration of action than that of morphine. Because of the opening of all the fused rings, piperidines are more flexible molecules. These drugs lack phenolic groups and thus are very lipophilic, thereby crossing the BBB more efficiently. For instance, fentanyl (93) is 100-fold more active than morphine. In total, 33 drugs having 4-phenylpiperidines and 4-anilinopiperidines as the backbone of their structure are used in the clinic, as shown in Figure 1. Orvinols are synthesized from alkaloid thebaine and possess structural rigidity. This rigidification increases their activity, improves their selectivity and reduces their side effects. For instance, in comparison with morphine, etorphine (98) is 10000 times more potent and crosses the BBB 300 times more easily. Reducing the double bond in etorphine yielded dihydroetorphine (99), which possesses 10-fold higher analgesic activity compared to etorphine. Thus, a total of 73 drugs have emerged from the morphine skeleton.

    β-Carboline Class

    Harmaline (2) and harmine (100) are β-carboline alkaloids isolated from Peganum harmala, which act as MAO inhibitors (Figure 2). Extracts of P. harmala and B. caapi are used traditionally in various forms, similar to in tinctures, due to their psychoactive effects.(19) β-Carboline is one of the structural classes of nonbenzodiazepines which have a clinically relevant affinity for benzodiazepine receptors. The drugs of this class in current clinical use are abecarnil (101), ZK-93423 (102), and DMCM (methyl-6,7-dimethoxy-4-ethyl-beta-carboline-3-carboxylate, 103). While searching the endogenous ligands for benzodiazepine receptors, Braestrup and co-workers purified β-carboline-3-carboxylic acid ethyl ester (βCCE) from normal human urine.(85) The discovery of βCCE, which has high affinity for benzodiazepine receptors, led to the synthesis of β-carboline derivatives like a very potent convulsant viz. DMCM (103). This is probable reason that β-carboline derivatives have ∼10-fold higher affinity for benzodiazepine receptors in comparison to diazepam. Thus, DMCM, being competitive antagonists/inverse agonists, is being used as a research tool to test new anxiolytic medications.(86)

    Capsaicinoids

    Capsaicinoids are secondary metabolites produced by the chili pepper. The structures of capsaicinoids that are in clinical use are shown in Figure 2. The active principle, capsaicin (3), exerts its effect by binding to the capsaicin receptor, i.e., the transient receptor potential vanilloid type 1 ion channel (TRPV1). Topical formulations containing capsaicin (3) are used for treating neuropathic pain. Nonivamide (104) is another capsaicinoid that is available as a topical formulation for treating arthritic and muscle pain.(87)

    Xanthine Scaffold

    The CNS stimulant xanthine alkaloid, namely, caffeine (4), was first isolated from Coffea arabica L. The consumption of strong black coffee improves breathing in asthmatic patients. Thus, dietary observations led to the discovery of the therapeutic benefits of caffeine (4) and theophylline (106).(25) Various analogues of caffeine were designed to enhance its potency and selectivity for biological targets (A1- and A2-adenosine receptors). The second generation compounds were designed to have improved antagonistic activity for their use as cardiotonic and cognition enhancers. The structural modification at various sites of theophylline has an impact on binding affinity for different subtypes (A1/A2) of adenosine receptors. Generally, 1- and 3-positions are modified together wherein a larger 3-position moiety enhance A1 receptor affinity, however, the 1-methyl group is essential for receptor affinity. 7-Methyl substitution reduces affinity for both A1 and A2 receptors. Affinity for A1 can be improved by phenyl, alkyl, and cyc1oalkyl substitution at the 8-position.(88) The medicinal chemistry of caffeine and theophylline led to the discovery of several xanthine derivatives with a wide range of therapeutic benefits, as depicted in Figure 2.

    Nicotine Scaffold

    Nicotine (5) is a cholinomimetic drug that exerts its stimulant effect by binding to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.(29) It is therapeutically used to treat nicotine dependence and is available in the form of chewing gums (Nicorette, Nicotex etc.), transdermal patches (NicoDerm, Nicabate P, Habitrol etc.), lozenges (NiQuitin CQ, Nicotinell, Commit etc.), and nasal sprays (NicAssist, Nicotrol NS etc.). However, it has limited medicinal use due to its undesirable side effects, which result from its interactions with other receptors. Anabasine (115) and cotinine (116) are nicotine analogues found in tobacco plants that possess similar effects to nicotine (Figure 2). Intact pyrrolidine ring is necessary and affects the binding affinity, for example, ring expansion to piperidine in the case of anabasine (115) results in reduced binding affinity.(89) Cotinine (116) is a major metabolite of nicotine and possess 3-fold less binding affinity compared to nicotine. It has a half-life of ∼15–19 h, which can be easily monitored in blood, urine, and saliva relative to nicotine (half-life 2–3 h).(90) These properties of cotinine make it a convenient and reliable biomarker to determine exposure to tobacco smoke from e-cigarettes.(91)

    Atropine Analogues

    Tropane alkaloids, namely, hyoscyamine (7), atropine (8), and scopolamine (118), are antimuscarinic agents. Atropa belladonna, Hyoscyamus niger, and Mandragora officinarum contain tropane alkaloids, and preparations of these plants have been used traditionally as psychostimulants.(32,92) Hyoscyamine, atropine, and scopolamine are important drugs today; however, their semisynthetic derivatives are even more important (Figure 2). Atropine is an enantiomeric mixture of d- and l-hyoscyamine, with most of its physiological effects due to the l-form. Hyoscyamine is a levorotary isoform of atropine. Being more lipophilic than atropine (log P 1.85), scopolamine (log P 2.25) shows better CNS effects due to higher BBB permeability. Semisynthetic derivatives of these NPs have been prepared with the aim of improving their PK/PD properties. For instance, homatropine (122) is less potent than atropine and hence used in diagnostic ophthalmology due to its more rapid but shorter duration of action, which can be controlled by physostigmine. The development of better tropane drugs than atropine led to the discovery of long-acting benzatropine (121) and tesofensine (132), for which the biological half-lives are 12–24 and 220 h, respectively. The semisynthetic drugs that are in clinical use also have the added advantage of higher BBB permeation over the parent NPs viz. atropine, hyoscyamine, and scopolamine. Log BB of all drugs in the tropane class is higher than 0.5, whereas it is −0.06 for atropine, indicating their superior therapeutic effects.

    Stigmine Derivatives

    Because of the anticholinergic properties of physostigmine (9), it is used as an antidote for Datura stramonium and Atropa belladonna poisoning (Figure 2). It can cross the BBB, enhances the transmission of acetylcholine in the brain, and is used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis. The SAR of physostigmine demonstrates that the carbamate group is essential for activity. The monomethyl carbamate in physostigmine is highly susceptible to hydrolytic cleavage. To overcome this, simpler analogues of physostigmine were prepared. For instance, miotine (137) was discovered; however, it was found to be susceptible to chemical hydrolysis and crosses the BBB, resulting in CNS-related side effects. To overcome both these issues, dimethyl carbamate derivatives of physostigmine, pyridostigmine (133), and neostigmine (134), were prepared. Because of the presence of the quaternary nitrogen in pyridostigmine and neostigmine, they do not cross the BBB and are thereby free of CNS-related side effects. Furthermore, using dimethyl carbamate instead of monomethyl carbamate improved the stability of the drugs.(92,93)

    Isoquinoline Motif

    Papaverine (11) is the well-known antispasmodic opium drug from the isoquinoline class. A total of 10 drugs based on this scaffold are used clinically, as shown in Figure 3. To reduce the toxicity profile of papaverine, different analogues were prepared. The ethyl analogue of papaverine, ethaverine (145), possesses 2–4-fold higher spasmolytic action. The added advantage of ethaverine is that it is not classified as a narcotic and possesses a toxicity profile one-third that of papaverine. Substituting the tetramethoxy group in papaverine with a tetraethoxy group possibly results in the reduced toxicity of ethaverine compared to papaverine. Papaverine is susceptible to thermal degradation, which converts it to papaveraldine, papaverinol, etc. Furthermore, other papaverine derivatives, for example, moxaverine (142) and eupaverin (144), are also superior to papaverine as mentioned above.(94)

    Ergoline Scaffold

    A tetracyclic ring system is present in ergot alkaloids and their derivatives. Ergot alkaloids are used to treat migraine headaches and Parkinson’s disease and as hallucinogens. Traditionally, they were used in small doses as an oxytocic. Semisynthetic derivatives of ergot alkaloids were prepared to improve their potency and reduce their adverse side effects. The ergoline scaffold served as the inspiration for the semisynthetic drugs bromocriptine (147), cabergoline (158), pergolide (159, treatment of Parkinson’s, dopamine agonists), and methysergide (160, migraine treatment). Ergot alkaloids have been subdivided into two chemical classes as shown in Figure 3. The first class is water-soluble amine ergots and their derivatives, which comprise 20% of total alkaloids. The other class is ergot amides, which are water-insoluble and are present at up to 80% of total alkaloids.(50,65) Lysergic acid derivatives are hallucinogens and generally classified as psychedelic drugs. LSD (19) has limited use and is an illicit recreational drug. However, semisynthetic derivatives of LSD, including ergometrine (153), lysergol (154), methylergometrine (155), lisuride (156), nicergoline (157), cabergoline (158), pergolide (159), methysergide (160), and amesergide (161), possess higher bioactivity compared to the parent NP. They act as agonists and antagonists depending upon their binding affinities for neuroreceptors.(95) Ergotamine (13) is the only medicinally used naturally occurring ergopeptine. The semisynthetic derivatives of ergotamine include bromocriptine (147), dihydroergotamine (148), and epicriptine (152). Thus, the ergoline scaffold has yielded 18 medicinally important drugs.

    Substituted Tryptamines

    N,N-DMT (18) is psychedelic drug contained in many plants all over the world, including Phalaris arundinacea, Phalaris aquatica, Phalaris brachystachys, Anadenanthera peregrina, Virola sebifera, and Banisteriopsis caapi. It has a similar structure to the neurotransmitters serotonin and melatonin. The functional analogues of N,N-DMT are shown in Figure 3, in which there are 22 CNS drugs that belong to the tryptamine scaffold. These compounds are MAO-inhibitors and some derivatives of tryptamine, including psilocin (24), psilocybin (162), 5-HO–DMT (172), ibogaine (179), and melatonin (180), are found in plants and fungi. The natural ligand of a target receptor has also served as a starting point during lead optimization. For instance, the starting point for the development of sumatriptan (165) was 5-HT, and sumatriptan was developed as a 5-HT1 agonist. Thus, all triptans are inspired by the natural ligand and are structural analogues of 5-HT.(96,97)

    Phenethylamine Skeleton

    Ephedrine (14) is an alkaloid from the phenethylamine class belonging to the genus Ephedra and a structural analogue of the neurotransmitters adrenaline and noradrenaline. Furthermore, it lacks the phenolic group of adrenaline and hence is not susceptible to metabolism by catechol-O-methyl transferase. This makes it more lipophilic than adrenaline, which increases its stimulant action by crossing the BBB. However, in 1927, ephedrine was available at high prices due to the monopolization of the supply of Ephedra vulgaris. To overcome this situation, an ephedrine analogue named amphetamine (15) was synthesized. On the other hand, amphetamine is also present in plants like Vachellia rigidula and Senegalia berlandieri. Amphetamine derivatives possess diverse therapeutic applications as CNS stimulants, ADHD treatments, and obesity treatments. These analogues are more lipophilic compared to amphetamine, thereby improving their CNS permeability. Amphetamine derivatives (Figure 4) compete with noradrenaline transport proteins that are responsible for the transport of the neurotransmitter noradrenaline into nerve cells. Because of this, noradrenaline is more slowly absorbed into the nerve cell, making it available for interaction at the receptor. Therefore, amphetamine and its derivatives exert an indirect agonist effect on the adrenergic system.(98) Substitution in amphetamine affects its hallucinogenic property. Structural modification in mescaline (16) at the α-position amplifies its potency. The reason for this might be facilitated CNS penetration and resistance to metabolic deamination of the side chain. Disubstitution at the α-position also inhibits the oxidative deamination like in phentermine (182), which is one of the most important reactions in drug metabolism catalyzed by cytochrome P450. α-Demethylation of amphetamine such as phenethylamine (194) decreases lipophilicity and thus increases its susceptibility to metabolism. Mono- and dimethoxylated derivatives, viz. 3-methoxy-4-methylamphetamine (186), 4-methoxyamphetamine (187), 3-methoxyamphetamine (191), etc., retain the hallucinogenic property of mescaline. N-Substituted amphetamine, for instance, methamphetamine (201), is more lipid soluble and thus more potent (clogBB 0.614) than amphetamine (clogBB 0.374). In the early twentieth century, designer amphetamines or substituted methylenedioxy-phenethylamines were discovered. These are ring-substituted amphetamines that are structurally similar to hallucinogens, e.g., mescaline (16), which possesses both stimulant and hallucinogenic properties. For example, 3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine (212) and 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (213) are used as recreational “love drugs”. Thus, a total of 49 drugs have emerged from the NPs ephedrine, amphetamine, and mescaline.

    Dopamine Motif

    Medical use of L-dopa (17) as medicine started after the discovery of dopamine as a neurohormone. It behaves as a prodrug and is converted to dopamine after entering the brain. Thus, it acts as a dopamine agonist and is administered to correct dopamine deficiency in Parkinson’s disease. Phenylalanine analogues including carbidopa (228), methyldopa (229), melevodopa (230), droxidopa (231), ciladopa (232), entacapone (233), and benserazide (234) were developed (Figure 4) and are being used in the management of Parkinson’s disease. These analogues are competitive inhibitors of the enzyme DOPA decarboxylase, which is responsible for the peripheral conversion of L-dopa to dopamine. Furthermore, peripheral dopamine does not have anti-Parkinson effects but only causes side effects. These drugs are also known as peripheral DOPA decarboxylase inhibitors that do not cross the BBB and thus block the inactivation of L-dopa to dopamine before it reaches the CNS.(99) In all, there are eight drugs inspired by the dopamine scaffold.

    Cathinone Derivatives

    Cathinone (235) is a monoamine alkaloid present in the leaves of Catha edulis (khat), indigenous to East Africa and the Arabian Peninsula, which are chewed. Cathinone is structurally similar to the neurotransmitters adrenaline, noradrenaline, and dopamine. Cathinone is β-keto amphetamine, and C═O functionality at the β-position of cathinone derivatives are the latest class of psychostimulant and hallucinogenic designer drugs and are shown in Figure 4.(100) However, cathinone derivatives, for instance, mephedrone (236), have no affinity for adrenoceptors because they lack phenol substitution, which is an important binding group for adrenergic agents. Their clinical utility is hindered due to the problem of abuse and dependence. For instance, methcathinone (245) was used initially as an antidepressant; however, it has been listed as a schedule I controlled substance due to abuse. Among these cathinone derivatives, bupropion (249) is the clinically most successful medication, which is widely prescribed as a treatment for depression and smoking cessation.(101)

    Cannabinoids

    The most notable psychoactive phytocannabinoids are cannabidiol (20) and tetrahydrocannabinol-THC (252), which act on cannabinoid receptors that alter the release of neurotransmitters in the brain. Cannabicyclohexanol (250) and cannabidivarin (251) are two cannabidiol-type cannabinoids that have clinical applications. They are structurally similar but differ in pharmacological activity. Cannabicyclohexanol is a hallucinogenic drug; however, cannabidivarin (251) is a nonpsychoactive drug that is being actively developed by GW Pharmaceuticals for treating epilepsy. Cannabinol (253) is a nonpsychoactive cannabinoid being used for its analgesic activity. Benzopyran ring is required for activity wherein ring-opened cannabidiol is inactive. Replacing of O– in benzopyran ring with N– in levonantradol (254) retain the activity. Furthermore, acyclic ring attachment to the benzopyran ring is essential for activity.(102) Analogues of the psychoactive cannabinoid THC were discovered with the objective of obtaining more potent derivatives of THC (Figure 5). For instance, the advantage of levonantradol (254) over THC is that it is water-soluble and therefore is easy to formulate and deliver. HU-210 (260) and nabilone (255) are synthetic cannabinoids. HU-210 is 100–800 times more potent than THC, while nabilone is used to treat neuropathic pain.(103,104) Nabiximols is a standardized extract of cannabis and is approved as a botanical drug in the UK. The oromucosal formulation consists of a mixture of THC and cannabidiol.(105)

    Yohimbine Class

    Reserpine (22) is an indole alkaloid and is used as an antipsychotic treatment. It exerts a sedative effect by blocking the transport of noradrenaline from the cytoplasm to synaptic vesicles. The accumulated noradrenaline is metabolized by the enzyme MAO, thereby decreasing the adrenergic activity.(71) Therapeutically used drugs from the yohimbine class are shown in Figure 5.

    GABA Analogues

    GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the CNS that reduces neuronal excitability, controls muscle tone, and exerts a sedative effect. One would think that the most straightforward approach for treating convulsions would be the administration of GABA. Unfortunately, polar GABA does not enter the CNS, and to solve this problem, lipophilic GABA analogues were synthesized.(106) Pregabalin (265) and gabapentin (272) were discovered accidentally. GABA analogues have different affinities for the GABAA and GABAB receptors. For instance, baclofen (267) is a GABA agonist that binds to specifically to the GABAB receptor, making it useful as a skeletal muscle relaxant. However, at higher doses, it exerts a sedating effect. Gabapentin is an analogue in which a cyclohexyl group was added to GABA with the objective of enhancing its BBB permeability.(107) Pregabalin (265) is the most active and lipophilic GABA analogue, which was developed for treating disorders such as epilepsy, neuropathic pain, and anxiety. The advantage of pregabalin over gabapentin is that it has excellent aqueous solubility which leads to rapid dissolution and therefore excellent oral bioavailability.(108) Vigabatrin (268) is a GABA transaminase inhibitor and reacts with GABA transaminase, which metabolizes GABA. Thus, it inhibits the depletion of GABA and is used as an antiepileptic agent. There are nine drugs formed from the GABA scaffold, as depicted in Figure 5.

    Thiamine Analogues

    Thiamine deficiency is the cause of Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome (WKS) and affects the CNS. WKS is a chronic neurological condition characterized by the loss of mental activity and muscle coordination, which can be treated by the administration of thiamine (274).(109) Structurally related but more lipophilic thiamine analogues have been developed, as shown in Figure 5, and are clinically used to treat CNS-related ailments. For instance, benfotiamine (275) is a lipid-soluble thiamine analogue used for treating diabetic nephropathy and has higher bioavailability than thiamine. Clomethiazole (279) is structurally related to thiamine and acts as a sedative, hypnotic, muscle relaxant, and anticonvulsant.

    Substituted Hydantoins

    The drugs derived or inspired from the NP allantoin (hydantoin core) are depicted in Figure 6. Phenytoin (281) is an antiseizure medication that shares pharmacophoric homology with the NP, allantoin (280). Allantoin is present in the plant comfrey (Symphytum x uplandicum), which is used as a traditional herbal medicine to treat inflammations and stimulate cell growth. Phenacemide (285) and pheneturide (286) are ring-opened analogues of phenytoin. The advantage of phenytoin over phenobarbital is that it causes less sedation. Furthermore, the pyrrolidine-2,5-dione scaffold (ethosuximide 306) and barbiturates (phenobarbital 287) also share the same pharmacophore with phenytoin and allantoin.(110) Subsequently, after phenobarbital, different barbiturates, shown in Figure 6, were discovered, with the objective of having anticonvulsant properties but without sedative properties or toxicity. For instance, short-acting secobarbital (291) and pentobarbital (302) are more lipid-soluble than long-acting phenobarbital and, as a result, enter the CNS rapidly and exert an effect after 30 min. The substitution of sulfur for oxygen produced thiopental (292) and thiamylal (303), which are highly lipid-soluble barbiturates.(111) After the Second World War, ethosuximide (306) and mesuximide (307) were discovered as drugs that are less toxic than trimethadione (305).

    Benzodiazepines

    Many benzodiazepines are used clinically as antianxiety drugs, antiepileptic agents, and hypnotics. Tomaymycin and anthramycin are antitumor antibiotics that are isolated from bacterial cultures of Streptomyces refuineus and Streptomyces achromogenes. The basic structural core of tomaymycin, anthramycin, and benzodiazepines is same, i.e., [1,4]-benzodiazepine.(112,113) The chemical classification of benzodiazepines is shown in Figure 7. Diazepam (309) is an analogue of benzodiazepine that has more pronounced muscle relaxant properties compared to chlordiazepoxide (308). Diazepam gets converted to the active metabolite nordazepam (318). The elimination half-lives of diazepam and nordazepam are higher, which is responsible for their prolonged action. Unfortunately, this results in accumulation of the drug during repeated administration. This led to the discovery of a new class of benzodiazepines based on the 3-hydroxy benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam (323) and oxazepam (325), which do not form this type of metabolite or for which the metabolite is rapidly eliminated. The reason for the quick elimination is the presence of the 3-hydroxyl group, which is glucuronidated in the liver. While in search of short-acting benzodiazepines, imidazo-benzodiazepines such as midazolam (331) and loprazolam (332) were discovered. Midazolam is formulated as the HCl salt and is the only water-soluble benzodiazepine available as an injection. The discovery of triazolo-benzodiazepines such as estazolam (327), alprazolam (329), and triazolam (330) as antidepressants is most encouraging because these drugs are very potent among the benzodiazepine class. Incorporation of the triazole ring results in a reduction in the half-life, enhanced absorption, fast elimination, and, furthermore, these derivatives are devoid of active metabolites, resulting in a more favorable therapeutic index in depressed patients.(114) Dibenzodiazepines such as clozapine (336) are valuable to schizophrenic patients who do not respond to conventional antipsychotic drugs. Replacing the benzene ring in clozapine with a thiophene ring yielded olanzapine (335), which has an improved safety profile over clozapine.(115)

    Tricyclic Antidepressants

    Malagashanine is an indole alkaloid isolated from Madagascan Strychnos species, namely, S. mostuoides, S. diplotricha, etc.(116) Tricyclic antidepressants share a common basic fragment, N-phenyl-1,3-diamino- and 1-phenyl-4-aminopropane, with malagashanine as shown in Figure 8.(117) Researchers have observed that a minor structural change in the central ring of imipramine (341) results in a change in the pharmacological activity of the compound. For example, replacement of −N in the central ring of chlorpromazine (365) with −S led to the discovery of thioxanthenes such as zotepine (379), which is used to treat acute and chronic schizophrenia. Furthermore, replacement of −S in the thioxanthene system resulted in the development of dibenzoannulenes, including nortriptyline (357) and amitriptyline (358). Different analogues of amitriptyline, namely dosulepin (377) and doxepin (378), were developed wherein −C in the central ring was replaced with −O. Replacement of −C with one or more heteroatoms in the central ring produced amoxapine (354). Sertraline (372) was derived from the structural modification of chlorprothixene (368), and this was followed by the discovery of a novel series of psychoactive compounds, including indatraline (373), lometraline (374), and tametraline (375), the clinically useful tricyclic antidepressants shown in Figure 8.(118)

    Miscellaneous NP-Based Drugs

    CNS drugs that do not fall under the above classes are discussed in this section (Figure 9). Myristicin (385) and elemicin (386) are members of a phenylpropene class of NP drugs isolated from nutmeg that possess psychoactive properties. Lobeline (387), cytosine (388), bilobalide (389), amantadine (390), rimantadine (391), memantine (392), bromantane (393), salvinorin A (394), l-tetrahydropalmatine (395), varenicline (396), tapentadol (397), and pterostilbene (398) are a few more NPs that are approved as CNS drugs.

    3. Synthetic Drugs for CNS Disorders

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    There are few scaffolds that are complete of synthetic origin, as depicted in Figure 10. These scaffolds include carbamates, such as meprobamate (399), carisoprodol (400), and felbamate (401), which are described as CNS muscle relaxants. However, meprobamate has largely been replaced by benzodiazepines due to their wider therapeutic index. Antidepressants of the morpholine class, including moclobemide (408) and viloxazine (409), were discovered accidentally. However, these drugs are not preferred due to their dangerous food interactions. To resolve this issue, tricyclic antidepressants were clinically explored. Risperidone (450) and paliperidone (451) belong to the benzisoxazole and piperidine scaffolds. The atypical antipsychotics melperone (454), benperidol (455), pipamperone (456), and bromperidol (457), which belong to butyrophenone class, are used for treating schizophrenia. The other scaffolds include benzamide, benzo[d][1,3]dioxole, piperazine, and 2,3-dihydro-1H-indene, as shown in Figure 10. The classical chromophores include 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroacridin (tacrine, 418), sulfamate-substituted fructose (topiramate, 422), benzothiazole (pramipexole, 423), and nitrobenzophenone (tolcapone, 424). CNS drugs of synthetic origin that do not fall under the above classes are shown in Figure 11.

    4. NPs and Their Drug Targets

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The reason for the slowing down of drug discovery in the CNS domain is the lack of biological understanding. For many first-in-class NPs and NP-derivatives with human efficacy, the biology was only discovered at a later stage. For example, morphine was discovered in 1804 in Germany by Friedrich Sertürner. However, its biological target, i.e., the opiate receptors, was discovered in 1973. Similarly, compounds such as amphetamine, apomorphine, and cannabidiol were known for their efficacy as CNS drugs, but their receptors (e.g., the dopamine and cannabinoid receptors) were discovered later on. The details of CNS drugs, their endogenous ligand(s), and the discovery of their receptors have been given in Table 2.
    Table 2. Discovery of CNS Drugs, Endogenous Ligand(s), and Receptors
    drugs (year of discovery)biology (year of discovery)endogenous ligand/agonistnew drugs
    morphine (1804)opiate receptors (1973)endorphins, enkephalin/encephalin, dynorphins(119,120)codeine, benzylmorphine, dihydrocodeine, oxycodone, methadone, etc.
     In 1978, neuroscientists Candace Pert and Solomon H. Snyderr eceived the Albert Lasker Award for the discovery of opioid receptors.  
         
    amphetamine (1987)dopamine receptors (1958)dopamine(121) (1910)salvinorin A, bromocriptine, cabergoline, ciladopa, L-dopa, etc.
    apomorphine (1951)In 1957, Kathleen Montagu was the first to identify dopamine in the human brain. The function of dopamine as a neurotransmitter was first recognized by Arvid Carlsson and Nils-Ake Hillarp in 1958. In 2000, Carlsson was awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for this discovery.  
         
    ergot alkaloids/ergotamine(122) (1918)5-Hydroxytryptamine receptors (1957)serotonin(123) (1948)sumatriptan, buspirone, rizatriptan, naratriptan, etc.
     Serotonin was discovered eight years before 5-HT receptors were reported.  
         
    cannabidiol (1963)cannabinoid receptors (1990)(124)endocannabinoids (eicosanoids and anandamide, 2-AG, noladin ether, virodhamine, N-arachidonoyl-dopamine)(124)tetrahydrocannabinol
         
    muscimol (1950)GABA receptors (1950)γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) (1883)(125)thiothixene, bupropion, caffeine, phenobarbital, etc.
         
    scopolamine (1880), pilocarpine (1874)acetylcholine receptorsacetylcholine (1915), muscarine (1869), and nicotine (1828)varenicline, cytosine, galantamine, lobeline, etc.
         
    dichloroisoproterenol (1958)adrenergic receptors (1875)norepinephrine (1934) and epinephrine (1897)phenylephrine, cocaine, prazosin, propranolol, etc.
     Paul Ehrlich proposed that receptors are selective and received Nobel Prize in Medicine for this discovery in 1908.(126)  
           
    caffeine (1819)adenosine receptor (1900)(127)adenosinetheophylline, theobromine, etc.
    Exploring new biological targets, pathways, and receptors involved in neurodegeneration may help to identify more ligands and thus potential therapies. Orphan receptors can also be explored as therapeutic targets in neurodegeneration, wherein novel neurotransmitters can be studied as natural ligands for these receptors.(128) Orphan receptors are structurally similar to other identified receptors but lack a ligand that activates them in vivo. One such receptor is the orphan G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), which exhibits a similar sequence to the opioid receptor. However, it is not known to bind any of the opioid peptides or synthetic opiates. Therefore, its natural ligand is unknown, making it an orphan receptor. In this approach, potential transmitters are randomly tested with the hope that one of the transmitters activates the matching orphan receptor.(129) There are many orphan receptors for which endogenous ligands have been discovered. In 1998, the G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) was deorphanized by isolation of the endogenous ligand apelin from bovine stomach tissue extracts. The peptide apelin has a role in many physiological systems and is associated with multiple biological actions in both the CNS and in the periphery.(130) The orphan receptor approach has led to the discovery of many neuropeptides including nociceptin, apelin, prolactin-releasing peptide, orexins/hypocretins, ghrelin, metastin, neuropeptide B/W, neuropeptide S, the prokineticins, relaxin 3, and neuromedin S. Thus, the “deorphanization” approach to orphan receptors can be explored to identify new bioactive peptides and new potential therapeutic targets.(131) Here, researchers can explore an opportunity to identify NPs as ligands for orphan receptors.

    5. CNS Drugs and Traditional Medicines

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    CNS drugs have deep roots in traditional medicines, specifically in China, India, and South Africa. Traditional medicine relies on herbal formulas as the principle treatment method for all diseases. Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM), Ayurveda, and Kampo (traditional Japanese medicine, TJM) have a more than 5000 year history and have played a very important role in treating diseases for humanity. The State Intellectual Property Office (SIPO) has examined patent applications related to natural medicines and reported that the number of traditional medicine patent publications in the world has already exceeded 50000.(132,133) The healthcare science of India, i.e., Ayurveda, originated from the Vedas and is based on the theory of Tridosha (vata, pitta, and kapha).(134) Traditional medicine in India has its unique system, concept, and method of diagnosis. The application of herbal medicines to treat the disease is based on theories. In African countries, the knowledge on the application of herbal medicines was handed down orally through many generations. Traditional African medicine believes that illness is derived from spiritual or social imbalance. The treatment involves herbal remedy that has healing and spiritual significance. There are more than 200000 traditional formulas in South Africa to heal and care for more than 27 million people.(135) Some plant species, listed in Table 3, are conventionally and traditionally used to treat neurological disorders in different countries.
    Table 3. Traditionally Used Herbs for CNS Disorders
    plant used as medicinecountry of origintherapeutic area/activityclass of compounds responsible for activityref
    American hellebore (Veratrum viride)United Statesepilepsyalkaloids, chemically similar to steroids(136)
    Blue cohosh/squaw root/papoose root (Caulophyllum thalictroides)United Statesconvulsionsquinolizidine alkaloids(137)
    kava (Piper methysticum)Western Pacificpsychotropic, anxiolytic, sedativekavalactones/kavapyrones(138)
    mistletoe (Phoradendron leucarpum)Europe, Western and Southern Asiaepilepsypolypeptide-viscotoxins(139)
    valerian (Valeriana officinalis)Europe, Asia, North Americasedative, anxiolytic, epilepsyvalerenic acids(140)
    skullcap (Scutellaria galericulata)Northern Hemisphere, Europe, Asia and Canadanerve tonic, anxiolytic, sedativescutellarin is a flavone-phenolic compound(141)
    marijuana (Cannabis sativa)Central and South Asiapsychoactivecannabinoids(142)
    qingyangsen (Cynanchum otophyllum)Southwest Chinaepilepsyglycosides(143,144)
    zhenxianling, Chinese herbal extract of white paeony root, cassia twig, Codonopsis pilosula, Pinellia ternate, bupleurum, Baical Skullcap root, liquorice, acid jujube kernel, fresh ginger, Chinese jujubeChinaepilepsyzhenxianling(145)
    saiko-keishi-to: mixture of nine crude herbal drugs viz Bupleurum falcatum, Paeonia lactiflora, Pinellia ternata, Cinnamomum cassia, Zingiber officinale, Zizyphus jujuba, Panax ginseng, Scutellaria baicalensis, and Glycyrrhiza uralensisJapansedative, hypnotic, and anticonvulsant (146)
    jin bu huan, Chinese herbChinasedative, antispasmodic, analgesicl-tetrahydropalmatine(147)
    Maypop/purple passionflower/true passionflower/wild apricot/wild passion vine (Passiflora incarnata)Southeast USanxiety and insomniaflavonoids, β-carboline alkaloids, and terpene derivatives(148)
    chamomile (Chamomilla recutita, Chamaemelum nobile)Southeast Europe and West Asiasedative, anxiolytic, and spasmolyticflavonoids(149)
    daffodils (Narcissus pseudonarcissus)Western Europe, GermanyCNS stimulantalkaloids(150)
    lemon balm (Melissa officinalis)South-Central Europesedative, anxiolyticrosmarinic acid, triterpenoid oleanolic acid, and ursolic acid(151)
    mulungu (Erythrina mulungu)Brazilsedative, insomnia, depressionalkaloid, erysotrine, erythravine(152)
    guarana (Paullinia cupana)Brazil, Amazon basinCNS stimulantxanthine alkaloids(153)
    yerba mate (Ilex paraguariensis)South AmericaCNS stimulantxanthine alkaloids(154)
    khat (Catha edulis)AfricaCNS stimulantalkaloids(155)
    kola nut/cola/kola/bitter kola (Cola nitida)West AfricaCNS stimulantalkaloids(156)
    St. John’s Wort (Hypericum perforatum L.)Europe, North Africa, and western Asiaanxiety, depression, insomnianaphthodianthrone, flavonoids(157)
    damiana (Turnera diffusa)Southern Texas in US, Central America, Mexico, South America, and Caribbeananxiolyticalkaloids, cyanogenic glycosides, flavonoids, and volatile oil(158)
    brahmi (Bacopa monniera), Ayurvedic medicineIndia, Australia, Europe, Africa, Asia, and North and South Americanerve tonic, epilepsy, sedative, memory enhancingalkaloids, saponins(159)
    muira puama (Ptychopetalum olacoides)Amazon rainforestnerve tonicditerpenoids(160)
    velvet bean (Mucuna pruriens), Ayurveda/Unani medicineAfrica and tropical AsiaParkinson’s diseaseL-dopa(161)
    Turkestan motherwort (Leonurus turkestanicus)-L. turkestanicus tea is energizing and calmingCentral Asia, Mongolia, Western Himalayas, Tibet, Xinjiang, and Irananxiety, sedative, neuralgia, nervous disordersflavonoids, phenolics, alkaloids, triterpenoids, essential oils(162)
    catnip (Nepeta cataria)US and Europesedative, spasmolytic, stimulantessential oils, iridoids, and iridoid glucosides(163)
    Oplopanax elatusRussia, Northern ChinaCNS stimulantsaponins, anthraquinones, phenylpropanoids, essential oils(164)
    Patrinia intermediaRussia, Central Asiatreating nervous excitementtriterpene saponins, phenolics acids, flavonoids, alkaloids(165)
    maral root (Rhaponticum carthamoides)Southern Siberia, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Eastern EuropeCNS stimulantecdysteroids, flavonoids, and phenolic acids(166)
    Panax ginsengChina, Korea, Russiainsomnia, anxiety, and depressiontriterpenoid saponins(167)
    polygala root/yuan-zhi (Polygala tenuifolia)China, Korea, Mongolia, Russiatranquilizer, improvement of intelligencexanthones, saccharide esters, flavonoids, triterpenoids(168)
    American basswood/American linden (Tilia americana)North America, Mexicosedative, anxiolytic, tranquilizer, convulsionsflavonoids(169)
    Galphimia glaucaMexicoSedative, treating mental disorders, anxiolyticnor-seco-triterpenes(170)
    tumbleweed (Boophone disticha)Africadementiaalkaloids(171)
    ayahuasca (Banisteriopsis caapi)Amazon basin, South Americahallucinogenic, psychedelicalkaloids(172)
    Indigenous people used these plants traditionally to cure or treat certain disorders. The form in which they were used is equally important. Native people had their own formulations and formulas that would yield the best CNS effect after consumption. For example, marijuana is smoked for its maximum psychoactive effect in Asian countries. Chamomile, yerba mate, catnip, and maral root are consumed in the form of tea for their CNS stimulant action. Guarana, native to Brazil, is taken internally as a CNS stimulant, in the form of soft drinks, powder, pastes, or sticks. The Russian plant Oplopanax elatus is formulated as a tincture for its CNS stimulant action. Patrinia intermedia is consumed in the form of a decoction, galenical, tincture for treating nervous excitement. Ayahuasca, native to the Amazon basin, is a traditional spiritual medicine consumed in the form of a brew or decoction. Indigenous people consume this brew during ceremonies because of its hallucinogenic and psychedelic effects. In the 16th century, a tincture of opium consisting of 10% opium powder (equivalent to 1% morphine) and wine was used to treat various ailments. This tincture, called “laudanum”, consisted of whole opium, which was first discovered by a Swiss physician and was sold without prescription until the 20th century. In the 18th and 19th centuries, “paregoric”, a tincture of camphorated opium (4% opium), was a household remedy for children that was widely used for its antidiarrheal, analgesic, and antitussive properties. A decoction of the powdered leaves of Psychotria curviflora was used as an anticonvulsant in Malaysia. Monoterpenoid indole alkaloids are most likely the components that give its medicinal properties. The seeds and hot water extract of nutmeg (Myristica fragrans), which is native to the Moluccas and the Banda Islands, were taken orally for their hallucinogenic properties.
    In European countries, there were many sacred herbal beverages, beers, or ales prepared by the fermentation of plants. These were used traditionally in specific rituals or spiritual disciplines due to their psychotropic effects. Gruit was the ale of the Netherlands and northern Germany, prepared from a combination of three narcotic herbs including Myrica gale, Achillea millefolium, and Ledum palustre. The consumption of this ale was known to result in narcotic, sedative, aphrodisiac, and psychotropic effects.(173) Sage ale was prepared by fermenting Salvia officinalis and was used throughout the Middle Ages due to its high medicinal value. In 1597, British researchers found that sage inhibits primary enzymes linked to Alzheimer’s disease and stated its efficacy for weak brains and memory. Broom (Cytisus scoparius) is a magical plant native to Europe. The two constituents of broom ale, scoparin and sparteine, are responsible for its diuretic, purgative, and narcotic effects. Henbane (Hyoscyamus niger), native to Eurasia, has been known for at least 5000 years for its medicinal value. Henbane possesses primarily narcotic and antispasmodic properties due to alkaloids such as hyoscyamine, scopolamine, and other tropane alkaloids. Henbane ale is prepared using henbane seeds, and this beer is used for treating insomnia, neuralgic pain, and for calming hysteria. Mandrake (Atropa mandragora) has been used traditionally as a medicine and in magical rituals as a sacred herb of Druids and in Wicca and Odinism. Mandrake beer was first brewed by the ancient Egyptians and is still being used due to its hallucinogenic properties. Darnel beer, a brew made from Lolium temulentum, contains a loline alkaloid, namely, temuline, which possesses sedative properties. It is rarely used as herbal medicine; however, it was used traditionally for pain relief and as a relaxant in nervous conditions. Wild lettuce ale is a fermented beer prepared using species of lettuce, namely, Lactuca virosa, which is commonly referred as lettuce opium. It is reported to possess sedative, relaxant, and analgesic properties. It was used by the ancient Egyptians and was in use until World War II. The analgesic and sedative properties of this ale are due to its chemical constituents, namely, lactucin and lactucopicrin.(174) Thus, traditional or ethnomedically known plant extracts possessing neurobiological activity also represent an attractive source of leads for CNS drug discovery.

    Successful Translation of Traditional Medicines into Modern Drugs

    Our ancestors obtained knowledge about medicinal plants and selected the species that could be ingested based on their effects on the body. Particularly with respect to CNS medicines, there are safe and effective new drugs that have been successfully obtained from the translation of traditional medicine. Traditionally, ergot alkaloids were smoked for their hallucinogenic properties. On the basis of the knowledge of its CNS effect, LSD was prepared from ergotamine and is now used for its psychedelic properties. Harmaline is a psychoactive indole alkaloid present in various plants including Peganum harmala and Banisteriopsis caapi. It was traditionally used in the beverage ayahuasca. Cannabidiol is a psychoactive drug extracted from Cannabis sativa. For many centuries, i.e., from 2800 BCE, smoking cannabis is known for its hallucinogenic and pain-relieving properties.(66) Psilocin, a tryptamine alkaloid known as a psychedelic drug, is isolated from psychoactive mushrooms known as “magic mushrooms”. In Mexico, this neurotropic fungus Psilocybe is used in religious ceremonies. In the 16th century, a Spanish monk illustrated the hallucinogenic properties of mushrooms when eaten with honey.(175) Cathine is a psychoactive stimulant drug naturally found and isolated from the leaves of Catha edulis. Traditionally, it is chewed as a stimulant in Africa and the Middle East. The leaves of Erythroxylon coca contain cocaine as the major alkaloid, which acts as CNS stimulant. For use as a stimulant, the leaves are chewed, or pure cocaine is sniffed or injected. Ephedrine is a stimulant that is taken by mouth, IV, IM, or SC. It was first isolated from the herb Ephedra and has been used for thousands of years in Asia and Midwest America.
    The NP-based library consisting of more than 500 compounds with drug-like properties has emerged from the analysis of over 120000 unique compounds in the Dictionary of Natural Products. This analysis showed that 65% of the compounds had no violations of Lipinski’s “rule of five”.(176) NPs and their combinatorial libraries can both be adopted for identification of leads. NP scaffolds like yohimbine(3) and galanthamine(177) have been effectively utilized for generation of small libraries.(178)
    Phenotypic screening and target-based screening are both preclinical strategies used for the identification of potential drug candidates. Phenotypic screening occurs before target identification, wherein the compound is exposed to systemic conditions to measure its biological effect in cells. This may involve monitoring multiple relevant pathways and targets. Typically, cell-based assays are used to measure the biological effects in cells, and this often involves monitoring multiple relevant pathways and targets simultaneously. To be more specific, phenotypic screening involves assay development, the screening of compounds to identify hits and leads, followed by target deconvolution. Phenotypic screening is one of the approaches for the discovery of new medicines and modern drugs, wherein the translation to human disease is more straightforward than target-based screening.(179,180) The first-in-class small molecules in the CNS domain that were discovered through phenotypic screening and approved by the FDA from 1999 to 2008 are aripiprazole, levetiracetam, memantine, rufinamide, varenicline, zonisamide, and ramelteon. However, during the same time period, only one FDA approved drug, ramelteon, was identified using target-based approaches.(9) Target-based screening is hypothesis-driven and involves identification of the target followed by its validation, assay development, and high throughput screening against the target, which gives hits and leads. The traditional herbs listed in Table 3 can be explored and examined in a drug discovery program by phenotypic screening. For instance, digoxin (isolated from foxglove in 1785), morphine (isolated from opium poppy in 1806), and aspirin (obtained by acetylation of the natural product salicylic acid in 1897) were derived from phenotypic screening.(14) Natural products can serve as structural backbones in the discovery of new drugs, as they possess a wide range of molecular targets and thus can compete with the substrates of multiple enzymes.

    6. What Is So Special about Natural Products?

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Natural products differ from synthetic molecules in many respects, such as their structural diversity, the complexity of ring systems, and diverse biological activities due to variations in interactions with receptors. These inimitable properties of NPs may serve as the starting point and these “privileged structures” can be modulated, resulting in multiple products that may emerge as new drugs.(181,182) For example, naltrexone is a synthetic opiate structurally similar to morphine, clinically used to treat opioid dependence, and possesses better safety and more selectivity for opioid receptors.
    Structurally, NPs and synthetic compounds differ from each other with respect to the number of chiral centers (there are more chiral centers in NPs in comparison with synthetic compounds, which contributes to their higher affinity and target specificity), the prevalence of aromatic rings (NPs tend to be rigid, with few rotatable bonds compared to synthetic compounds, which results in higher selectivity for NPs), the introduction of complex ring systems, the degree of saturation of the molecule, and differences in heteroatoms (the relative abundance of sulfur in NPs is very low in comparison to synthetic compounds).(2,183) A typical characteristic of NPs that differentiates them from synthetic compounds is their chirality, both unichirality and homochirality. In the prescientific era, herbal remedies were used without any knowledge of the chirality of molecules. We compared the NPs, NP-derived drugs, NP-inspired drugs, and synthetic drugs that were covered in sections 2 and 3 for the presence of chiral centers in their structures. We found that the percentage distribution of drugs with the presence of chiral centers is much higher in NPs and NP-inspired drugs in comparison to synthetic drugs. To be more specific, the percentage distributions of drugs with chiral centers in NPs/NP-inspired drugs and synthetic drugs are 59% and 41%, respectively (Figure 12a). Chirality is a hallmark of many NPs and may demonstrate enantioselective pharmacological activity by interacting with the target protein. For example, the enantiomers of hyoscyamine (7), l-hyoscyamine, and d-hyoscyamine display different pharmacological activities. The CNS stimulant effect of d-hyoscyamine is greater than that of l-hyoscyamine. Another example is amphetamine (15), which is a potent CNS stimulant and is used to treat ADHD. Amphetamine is a racemic mixture of d-amphetamine and l-amphetamine. The latter is less potent than d-amphetamine for producing a stimulatory effect. The prescribed amphetamine formulations, e.g., Adderall and Mydayis, contain both enantiomers in a ratio of 3:1. Muscarine (12) is a nonselective agonist of the muscarinic acetylcholine receptor, which is found and isolated from species of mushrooms, particularly the Inocybe and Clitocybe species. Muscarine shows distinct and remarkable stereospecific activity wherein d-muscarine is more potent than l-muscarine, which possesses only 0.1% of the activity of d-muscarine.(184) Pilocarpine is an alkaloid and muscarinic receptor agonist that isomerizes into isopilocarpine under basic conditions. The chemical decomposition of pilocarpine to isopilocarpine results in the loss of the pharmacological activity of pilocarpine. Morphine (1) has five chiral centers in its structure, and its stereochemistry is important for its pharmacological activity. l-Morphine is a natural compound possessing opioid/analgesic activity, wherein d-morphine, which was synthesized in 1960, lacks analgesic activity and instead possesses antitussive activity.(185) This is because l-morphine interacts with binding sites via three functionalities (t-amine, phenolic hydroxyl and aromatic ring); however, because of the orientation of d-morphine, only one functionality (the aromatic ring) is available for binding to active site residues. LSD, 19, is a chiral compound having two optical isomers. However, only d-LSD possesses psychedelic action whereas l-LSD is a psychotropically inactive enantiomer having 1000-fold lower activity than d-LSD.(186)
    Structural rigidity provides strong binding affinity with the target protein and thus contributes to the higher selectivity and improved potency of the molecule. Therefore, medicinal chemists can consider increasing the rigidity of molecules as a factor in lead optimization to gain ligand affinity with the target protein. The presence of a large number of rings, fused rings, etc., in the molecule is one important parameter that determines the structural complexity and rigidity of molecules. The median of the number of rings for NPs/NP-inspired drugs and synthetic drugs are 2.83 and 1.95, respectively. Similarly, the mean number of fused rings in NPs/NP inspired drugs (2.71) was much higher (almost double) than that of synthetic drugs (1.29). These numbers clearly show that the NPs/NP inspired compounds in the CNS domain cover a much wider chemical space and complexity than the synthetic drugs (Figure 12b). In addition to this, NPs advance a rich collection of molecular frameworks that hold desirable drug-like properties, making them ideal starting points for chemical modification.(187) Thus, structurally characterized pure NPs may provide a unique opportunity for exploration in drug discovery programs.
    Furthermore, NPs and NP derivatives can be differentiated from synthetic drugs by their unique characteristics, such as their active transport across BBB (via NP-specific ATP dependent transporter proteins), their isoform selectivity, their evolutionary interactions with plants, herbivores, and insects, and the drug-like and lead-like characteristics of NPs in the CNS domain. Almost all NPs are agonists of one receptor or another.

    Special Ability of NPs/NP-Inspired Drugs to Cross the Blood–Brain Barrier

    In the CNS domain, the BBB is frequently a limiting factor for permeation of drugs into the brain. It is now generally accepted that synthetic drugs follow Lipinski’s rule of five and cross membrane barriers through passive diffusion. On the contrary, NPs do not generally follow Lipinski’s rule and are mostly transported actively across biological membranes (via class specific ATP dependent ABC transporters). This phenomenon is more pronounced in the case of active transport of NPs crossing BBB. The BBB regulates brain homeostasis by preventing and controlling the access of solutes and toxic substances to the CNS. The lipophilic nature of the cell membrane is an important determinant for the passive entry of drugs into the CNS. BBB permeability or the brain/plasma partition may be altered by reducing the molecular weight, the number of hydrogen bonds, P-glycoprotein efflux, or by modulating the lipophilicity. The efflux transporter P-glycoprotein (P-gp) prevents the significant accumulation of many hydrophobic drugs in the CNS.(188,189) P-gp may hamper the uptake of several drugs into the brain, contributing to the limited success rate of CNS drug therapies. Co-administration of P-gp substrates with CNS drugs may represent a novel therapeutic approach to overcome BBB permeability issues.(190) Low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 1 (LRP1) is a multifunctional endocytic receptor highly expressed in the brain and the liver, which regulates the balance between degradation and production of Aβ peptide. This balance of extracellular Aβ is a major hallmark of patients suffering from Alzheimer’s disease.(191) On the basis of permeability, Vilar et al. classified compounds into three categories: (a) compounds with log BB ≥ 0.3, that readily cross the BBB, (b) compounds with log BB between 0.3 and −1, which still have access to the CNS, and (c) compounds with log BB < −1, which have poor distribution in the brain.(192) We computed the log BB values of NPs/NP-inspired and synthetic drugs. This analysis was performed to determine the percentage distribution of CNS drugs with clogBB values ranging from −2.0 to −1.0, −1.0 to 0, 0 to 0.5, 0.5 to 1 and 1 to 2, which is shown in Figure 12c. The analysis clearly shows that ∼32% of NPs/NP-inspired drugs have log BB values in the range of 0–0.5, which is higher than that for synthetic drugs (∼17%). We also calculated the percentage distribution of drugs that have access to the CNS in terms of the log BB value (−1 and above) for both NPs/NP-inspired drugs and synthetic drugs. Almost 91% and 78% of the compounds belonging to the NP/NP-inspired and synthetic groups, respectively, can be classified as “drugs having access to the CNS”.
    BBB permeability can be improved by structural modifications. This can be achieved either by reducing the number of hydrogen bonds, by modulating lipophilicity, or by replacing carboxylic acid groups. For instance, the combined effect of the molecular characteristics of oxycodone (37) and oxymorphone (36) on BBB efflux is shown Figure 13. The physicochemical properties of oxycodone and oxymorphone are similar except for their log P, log BB, and PSA. The octanol/water partition coefficient (log P) of oxycodone is more than oxymorphone, 1.9 versus 1.4. The total number of HBD and HBA is less for oxycodone, 7.25, than that for oxymorphone, 7.75. Log BB for oxycodone is higher than that of the oxymorphone, 3.0 versus 0.23. Oxycodone is an opioid analgesic that is metabolized to oxymorphone via CYP2D6. However, in the clinic, the analgesic efficacy is due to the parent molecule oxycodone because oxymorphone is produced in a very low concentration (approximately <5%) in plasma and in CSF (cerebrospinal fluid), which demonstrates its limited brain permeation.(193,194) These properties altogether may contribute to the rapid and high brain uptake of oxycodone.
    The effects of lipophilicity and structural modification on BBB permeation have been exemplified using morphine (1) and codeine (6). Codeine and heroin (28) possess higher log P values than morphine (1.14 and 1.86 versus 0.24, respectively), which results in a 10- and 100-fold increase in BBB permeation for codeine and heroin in comparison with morphine (Figure 14). Codeine and heroin also have less H-bond donors (HBD is 1 and 0, respectively) compared to morphine (HBD = 2), which is a dominant determinant of BBB permeability. The literature also states that the brain uptake of morphine is negligible in comparison to that of codeine and heroin, which are 24% and 68%, respectively.(195,196)O-Demethylation of codeine in the presence of CYP2D6 enzymes produces morphine in vivo. This conversion is necessary to achieve the analgesic activity of morphine. In this particular case, the addition of a methyl group to morphine produces codeine, which increases BBB permeability. However, N-demethylation of codeine and morphine results in the formation of norcodeine and normorphine, respectively, which do not have any pharmacological activity.(197) The N-methyl functionality is required for the pharmacological activity of morphine. Blocking of −H by a cleavable group is an alternative approach for medicinal chemists to improve the BBB permeation of a morphine-like scaffold.(198)

    Isoform Selectivity of NP Drugs

    NPs have different affinities for different proteins, which is called as an isoform-specific activity. There are several candidates in preclinical and clinical development for CNS protein kinases. The protein kinase target GSK3 (glycogen synthase kinase 3) regulates various cell functions and is linked to numerous pathological conditions, including Alzheimer’s disease. In mammals, GSK3 is encoded in two isoforms, GSK3α and GSK3β. Overexpression of GSK3β increases tau phosphorylation, thereby affecting cognitive impairment.(199) Therefore, inhibition of GSK3β activity provides neuroprotective effects, decreased amyloid-β production and reduced tau hyperphosphorylation. Manzamine A, a neuroprotective alkaloid isolated from Indonesian sponge, Acanthostrongylophora, is a selective inhibitor of GSK3β. It is reported to decrease the hyperphosphorylation of tau proteins and can be explored as a potential therapeutic agent for Alzheimer’s disease.(200) Apigenin is a flavonoid found in many plants including chamomile. Traditionally, in Southeast Europe, chamomile tea is used as a treatment for insomnia and anxiety. Apigenin contributes to the activation of GABAA by selectively binding to the receptor and thus reduces anxiety.(201) The added advantage of selective isoform inhibition may lead to an improved safety profile for the drug candidate. Muscimol is a psychoactive constituent isolated from Amanita muscaria and is a selective agonist for GABAA receptors. Structurally, it contains an isoxazole ring, which is responsible for the selectivity of muscimol for GABAA receptors. It has a structural resemblance to the endogenous ligand GABA. Through molecular modeling studies, Balle and co-workers have shown that muscimol interacts with the GABAA receptor in a similar fashion to that of GABA. The interaction of the terminal NH2 of GABA with the Ser-156 residue is mimicked by the NH2 group present in muscimol. The nitrogen of the isoxazole ring and the 3-OH group present in isoxazole mimic the interactions of the carboxylic acid group of GABA (with the Thr-202, Arg-66, and Arg-131 residues).(202)
    In addition to the existing paradigm of “one-drug-one-target”, an additional approach based on polypharmacology (simultaneous engaging a set of related targets) is also being explored in multifactorial CNS diseases. One of the recent examples of this approach is the approval of Sativex (nabiximols), a new drug for neuropathic pain, which is 1:1 mixture of delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (Δ9-THC) and cannabidiol (CBD).(203,204) Natural products possess unique and diverse chemical properties which inhibit a number of proteins and lipids involved in neurodegeneration.(205) Phytocannabinoids are a class of compounds that bind to cannabinoid receptors. There are two subtypes of cannabinoid receptors, CB1 and CB2. The CB1 receptor is mainly expressed in the brain and is responsible for the psychoactive effect of cannabinoids. However, the CB2 receptor is distributed in peripheral cells and in the immune system and as a result is involved in a large spectrum of diseases including pain, immune, and inflammatory disorders. Δ9-THC is a psychoactive cannabinoid as it has a higher binding affinity for the CB1 receptor agonist.(206) However, oxidation, isomerization of B ring, C ring opening, and side chain variation in Δ9-THC results in either a change or loss of psychoactivity (Figure 15).
    Oxidation of Δ9-THC yields cannabinol, which is a CB2 ligand and thus possesses analgesic activity. Δ8-THC is obtained upon isomerization of ring B in Δ9-THC. This isomerization is responsible for the loss of psychoactivity. Furthermore, C-ring opening in Δ9-THC results in the formation of cannabidiol, which exerts its analgesic activity by binding to the CB2 receptor. Side chain variation in Δ9-THC provides THCV, which is a CB1 receptor antagonist.(207) Ladostigil is a multifunctional neuroprotective drug being investigated for treating neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. Ladostigil inhibits MAO-A and MAO-B, exhibiting antidepressant activity. It also acts as a ChE inhibitor, thereby improving attention and cognitive function.(208) Pergolide is an ergoline-based drug used clinically for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. It acts on multiple targets including dopamine D1R and D2R and is a serotonin receptor agonist. D1R is the most abundant receptor in the CNS, regulating neural growth and development; however, D2R is the main receptor for all antipsychotic drugs.(209) Bromocriptine and cabergoline selectively bind to D2R and to serotonin receptors.(210)

    Evolutionary Interaction among Plants, Herbivores, and Insects

    Chemical ecology also has a significant contribution in the identification of therapeutic targets against different diseases. The mutual and antagonistic species interactions between plants have given rise to ecological and evolutionary consequences. The coevolution between plants and herbivores is responsible for the diversity in plant defenses, which subsequently lead to evolutionary changes in herbivores. The evolutionary biologists who have explored plant–herbivore interactions argue that most plant secondary metabolites are potent neurotoxins which were evolved to prevent the consumption of plants by herbivores. For instance, nicotine, arecoline, cocaine, ephedrine, caffeine, theophylline, theobromine, morphine, and Δ9-THC are plant secondary metabolites and are the most common psychoactive drugs.(211,212)
    To reduce insect attacks on plants, they develop different mechanisms, including the activation of different metabolic pathways that significantly alter their chemical and physical properties. Further, insects have developed several strategies to defeat plant defenses that allow them to feed, grow, and reproduce on the host plant. In contrast, plants produce two different types of defensive chemicals, toxic substances that repel insects and inducible chemicals that are synthesized in response to tissue damage by insects. For example, vicillin, a globulin found in leguminous seeds, strongly binds to the chitin-containing structures present in the midguts of insects, cell walls, and the membranes of fungi and yeast. This in turn negatively interferes with the growth and development of attacking organisms.(213,214)
    Nature assists our drug discovery efforts, as many compounds synthesized by microorganisms and plants are used directly as drugs. A number of intraspecific or interspecific semiochemicals exist, which act as neurotransmitters.(215) The concurrent ecological interactions between plants, insects, and herbivores may give rise to the discovery of therapeutic targets and ligands.(216) There are a number of natural products that emerged as CNS drugs and are in clinical use for treating neurodegenerative disorders. The important origin of the therapeutic efficacy of NPs may be the existence of analogous neurotransmitters and receptors in plants, insects, herbivores, vertebrates, and mammals. There are a number of neurotransmitters, neuromodulators, and receptors that are common between plants and vertebrates, such as acetylcholine, epinephrine, dopamine, levodopa, GABA, glutamate, and serotonin.
