Therefore, secondary metabolites produced by plants show therapeutic efficacy in human beings and may provide leads for drug discovery programs.

    Drug-Like/Lead-Like Characteristics of NPs in the CNS Domain

    Molecules cross BBB to enter CNS by three broad mechanisms: (a) passive unidirectional diffusion driven by concentration gradient and (b) facilitative diffusion by nonenergy dependent transporters, e.g., glucose transporters. The third mechanism involves energy-dependent (ATP) active transport against the concentration gradient, e.g., transport of neurotransmitters and other biomolecules. Generally low molecular weight (<400 Da) and lipophilicity favor drug uptake in CNS cells and tissues. However, too much lipophilicity can lead to sequestering of the molecules in capillaries and peripheral tissue lowering the concentration in the blood.(217,218) In addition to the optimum lipophilicity (clogP ≈ 2–5), the other factors such as charge, tertiary structure, and protein binding also contribute to the drug uptake and free drug concentration in CNS.(219) The in vivo efficacy of any drug molecule is dependent on free (unbound) drug concentration. Only free drug molecules interact with the therapeutic target (such as enzymes, transporters, or receptors) to produce efficacy. The free drug hypothesis is very important in drug discovery and development to establish a pharmacokinetic–pharmacodynamic (PK–PD) relationship, to predict the therapeutically relevant dose, and to monitor drug concentration in clinical studies. There are two concepts which form free drug hypothesis: (i) the free drug concentration (Cu) is same on both sides of biomembrane at the steady state provided there is no involvement of any active transporter and (ii) only the free (unbound) drug concentration (Cu) at the site of action is responsible for its pharmacological activity in vivo.
    In part-(i) of the free drug hypothesis, Cu is same on both sides of biomembrane (plasma/brain) at steady state where the rate of membrane permeation of drug is high. There are exceptions to this hypothesis where steady-state equilibrium may not be reached if (a) drugs with a slow rate of membrane permeation will have low Cu in biophase than in plasma, (b) drugs having low distribution to the cells will not be effectively delivered to the target due to low discontinuous blood flow to the tissue, (c) drugs that are substrates of efflux transporters (for example, P-glycoprotein) will have reduced Cu on the therapeutic target, and (d) drugs that are uptake transporter substrates (for example, l-amino acid transporter 1) will have increased Cu into the tissue of the therapeutic target. As stated by Smith et al.,(220) in the free drug hypothesis part-(ii), it is Cu at the site of action that is responsible for the biological activity (in vivo efficacy and toxicity). The total drug concentration (Ctotal) or the concentration of drug bound to plasma/tissue proteins (Cb) is not responsible for the biological activity, in vivo. Therefore, when assessing the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic relationships, it is important to determine Cu in the biophase system (for instance, brain) instead of determining Ctotal.
    As discussed in detail by Smith et al.,(220) it is recommended that while designing compounds, the data obtained from in vitro plasma protein binding assay where free drug fraction (fu) of a compound is measured should not be used as a guide, the fu = Cu/Ctotal, which is expressed as a decimal or percentage. However, there is a chance of error while predicting in vivo efficacy from extrapolating Cu from in vitro PPB data. This is because living systems exert many simultaneous physiological actions on the drug molecules (for example, binding to the target, PPB, metabolism, transport, and movement between cellular and tissue compartments). Furthermore, in vitro experiments are static, with a limited number of simultaneous actions on drug molecules. Therefore, in vivo efficacy is determined by Cu at the therapeutic target and not by fu. The decisions based on fu may result in the wrong compounds being advanced through drug discovery program. The changes in structural variables such as log D, pKa, and PSA affect the metabolic clearance, renal clearance, absorption, and dissolution. The increase in plasma Cu is primarily because of the reduced intrinsic clearance and not due to change in PPB. Therefore, in a drug discovery program, PPB should not be measured until in vivo evaluation of the compound is done. Furthermore, the approach of determining log BB can be misleading. Log BB is expressed as the ratio of the concentration of a compound in the brain and in the plasma. Here, the total drug concentration (Ctotal = Cb + Cu) in the brain and blood samples is measured to calculate brain/plasma ratio. Therefore, in addition to log BB, Cu should be measured. As stated by Smith et al., PPB of a drug has little effect on the in vivo efficacy. Moreover, it is Cu at the therapeutic target which can be enhanced by improving solubility and by reducing drug efflux that is crucial for in vivo activity. In brief, additional measurement of Cu along with log BB is the more relevant strategy for developing PK–PD relationships in neuroscience projects.(220)
    Brain permeation of basic molecules is favored at pH 7–8. Mostly the NPs and NP-derived CNS drugs are basic and, under physiological conditions, they exist in equilibrium between charged and neutral states. In addition to this, compounds with tertiary nitrogen show a higher degree of brain permeation.(221) The neurotransmitters are amines, amino acids (glutamate, GABA, and glycine), peptides (CCK, endorphins, somatostatin), and nucleosides (adenosine), which are common in plants. The most often used descriptors and their cutoff values for BBB permeation while balancing considerations of pharmacokinetic and pharmaceutical properties are as follows: molecular weight (MW) < 400–500 Da, H bond donor (HB donor) < 3, H bond acceptor (HB acceptor) < 7, log D 1–3, polar surface area (PSA) < 60–70 Å, pKa 7.5–10.5, and N + O < 6.(222,223) We performed CNS MPO (central nervous system multiparameter optimization) analysis for CNS drugs, both NP/NP-inspired and synthetic drugs to find out their alignment for drug-like properties.(224,225) The drug-like properties of these compounds, including their MW, HB donor, HB acceptor, log P, log D, PSA, pKa, and N + O, were computed using the QuikProp module of the Schrodinger software. Interestingly, we observed that more than 70% of both NP/NP-derived and synthetic CNS drugs qualified concerning drug-like properties (ClogP, ClogD, MW, PSA, HBD, and pKa) based on their CNS MPO score (T0 = 1) (Figure 12d). We also compared the % distribution of both NP/NP inspired and synthetic drugs for the perfect CNS MPO score, T0 = 1. The analysis showed that the distribution of NPs/NP-inspired and synthetic drugs is same for ClogP (∼62–67%), ClogD (∼61–62%), and HBD (∼27–29%). However, a PSA of NP/NP-inspired drug is lower than the synthetic ones (∼41 and 68%, respectively). Furthermore, perfect CNS MPO score T0 = 1 with respect to MW and pKa was higher for NPs/NP-inspired drugs (∼84 vs 67% and 34 vs 27%, respectively) in comparison with synthetic drugs. The reason for this may be that most of the NPs, for instance, alkaloids contain nitrogen in their structure, making them basic in nature which is associated with their active efflux at the BBB (via targeting monoamine GPCRs and transporters). The basic pharmacophore like amine functionality has a very important role in the CNS activity of compounds. Positively charged amines predominantly interact with the negatively charged groups of phospholipids at the BBB. On the other hand, acidic drugs typically show poor BBB permeation in comparison with drugs containing amine functionalities. The reason for this is their low membrane affinity and thereby low intrinsic permeability.(226) Furthermore, the number of synthetic drugs in desirable pKa range is low (∼27%). The reason for the absence of basic amines in synthetic drugs could be by their design to minimize the risk of adverse events such as hERG liability and drug-induced phospholipidosis. Furthermore, BBB permeability of neutral drugs is lower than the bases as they interact to a lesser extent with the lipid portion of membranes. The neutral compounds are transported by carrier protein or by passive diffusion and are ranked for BBB permeability as basic > neutral > acidic.(217)

    Almost All NPs Are Agonists

    Biological responses are produced by chemical (agonists) activation of receptors. Agonists are either endogenous or exogenous ligands that bind to the receptor. Neurotransmitters are endogenous ligands that are responsible for neuronal signal transmission. Most of the psychoactive NPs possess a structural resemblance with endogenous neurotransmitters and thus mimic their action and are known as the agonist (Figure 16). For instance, amphetamine and methamphetamine are structurally similar to dopamine and noradrenaline and therefore act as sympathomimetic psychostimulants. The pharmacological profile of MDMA is similar to that of serotonin due to their structural similarity.(227)
    There are so many NPs, NP-derivatives, and NP-inspired drugs in the clinic because they have proven their efficacy in humans. The majority of chemicals produced by microorganisms or plants are not meant to bind to human proteins. Rather, these chemicals are produced by plants and microorganisms for self-defense. One might wonder why these chemicals show pharmacological effects on the human body. The answer to this may be the finite structural similarity between the proteins present in plants, insects, microorganisms, and herbivores. Human drug targets may contain similar structural domains with which NPs have coevolved. Briefly, NPs have been evolved to interact with “something” and this “something” does not differ from human proteins. The interaction between NPs and their receptors has been a source of inspiration for the discovery of new therapeutic targets. Almost all NPs are agonists as they may interact with small and large ligands to exert pharmacological responses.

    New View of the Pharmacology of NPs: Xenohormesis

    For almost a century of modern chemistry, the small-molecule natural products from plant and microbial species were considered to be the byproducts of the primary metabolism (hence termed secondary metabolites!) and considered to be produced to protect the plant species from animal and insect predators or as phytoalexins (antibiotics). However, when one looks the current knowledge of the natural products from plants and their biological receptor systems in human/animal biology, the prevailing predator/phytoalexin hypothesis does not hold well and it becomes obvious that the NPs have evolved for various indispensable and symbiotic biological functions for the species–species biochemistry, signaling, and growth. Interestingly, two complementary components (ligands and receptors) of a given biological pathway are found in two altogether different living domains. For example, opiate receptors of CNS are present in human biology but their ligands (morphine class of alkaloids) are in plant species and cannabinoid receptors CB1/CB2 are in human biology and the ligands (THC and CBD) are in Cannabis species. Quite remarkably, this is the common recurring theme in CNS biology: the receptor in human biology and the ligand in plant biology. In fact, most of the CNS active NPs (listed in Table 1) were discovered first from the plant/microbial species, but their macromolecular receptors were discovered in mammalian biology much later, even after decades or centuries. More interestingly, the endogenous ligands (e.g., endorphins and endocannabinoids) of the CNS receptors (e.g., opiate and CB1/CB2) were discovered much later. In fact, the endogenous ligands of many CNS receptors have yet to be identified.
    In this context, a new hypothesis was recently proposed(228) by David Sinclair, which envisages a much deeper evolutionary relationship between autotrophic (plants) and heterotrophic (animals) species through small-molecule natural products. The hypothesis termed as xenohormesis proposes that the animals (the heterotrophs) have evolved the mechanisms to sense stress and signaling induced compounds from the plants (the autotrophs) that are under selective evolutionary pressure to synthesize these natural products. This process confers selective survival advantages for both autotrophic and heterotrophic partners, as the stress in one organism benefits the other and vice versa. One of the best examples of such synergy driven by xenohormesis is the salicylate/jasmonate pathway in plants and related prostaglandin-mediated pain pathway in mammalian biology. Such interspecies signaling pathways are invariably present in CNS with reference to a plant-derived natural product, which is further facilitated by their active transport across BBB of CNS.

    7. Conclusion and Outlook

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Natural product chemistry for neuroscience drug discovery remains challenging. However, NPs and NP derivatives possess an exceptionally different chemical space in comparison to synthetic drugs. Importantly, the core ring scaffold that is present in NPs is absent in most of the synthetic drugs that are in the clinic. Therefore, the addition of an NP-like scaffold would increase the hit rate in drug discovery programs. Looking ahead, NPs have been extensively developed in historical drug discovery research. There is no doubt of the resurgence of natural-product-based drugs, as emphasized by the number of drugs commercially available and in clinical trials for the treatment of cancer, infections, and immunological and CNS-related diseases within modern NP research. Nevertheless, there is an important need to explore the structural biology of NPs in neuroscience drug discovery, and the lack of this detailed understanding offers a unique opportunity for medicinal chemists working in collaboration with biologists. Expanding the investigation of natural sources with an emphasis on neurodegenerative diseases is likely to identify novel lead compounds and new chemical tools to better understand the complex etiology of CNS disorders.

    cannabinoid receptor type 2

    THCV

    tetrahydrocannabivarin

    ChE

    cholinesterase

    D1R

    dopamine receptor-1

    2R

    dopamine receptor-2

    MW

    molecular weight

    PSA

    polar surface area

    MDMA

    3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine

      Koehn, F. E.; Carter, G. T. The evolving role of natural products in drug discovery. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2005, 4, 206– 220,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd1657

      3
      The evolving role of natural products in drug discovery
      Koehn, Frank E.; Carter, Guy T.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2005), 4 (3), 206-220CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Natural products and their derivs. have historically been invaluable as a source of therapeutic agents. However, in the past decade, research into natural products in the pharmaceutical industry has declined, owing to issues such as the lack of compatibility of traditional natural-product ext. libraries with high-throughput screening. However, as discussed in this review, recent technol. advances that help to address these issues, coupled with unrealized expectations from current lead-generation strategies, have led to a renewed interest in natural products in drug discovery.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhslSnsrg%253D&md5=ce80052abaa76430220ee5981138053e
    4. 4
      Harvey, A. L.; Edrada-Ebel, R.; Quinn, R. J. The re-emergence of natural products for drug discovery in the genomics era. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2015, 14, 111– 129,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd4510
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      The re-emergence of natural products for drug discovery in the genomics era
      Harvey, Alan L.; Edrada-Ebel, RuAngelie; Quinn, Ronald J.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2015), 14 (2), 111-129CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Natural products have been a rich source of compds. for drug discovery. However, their use has diminished in the past two decades, in part because of tech. barriers to screening natural products in high-throughput assays against mol. targets. Here, we review strategies for natural product screening that harness the recent tech. advances that have reduced these barriers. We also assess the use of genomic and metabolomic approaches to augment traditional methods of studying natural products, and highlight recent examples of natural products in antimicrobial drug discovery and as inhibitors of protein-protein interactions. The growing appreciation of functional assays and phenotypic screens may further contribute to a revival of interest in natural products for drug discovery.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsVarsbg%253D&md5=b871148315dc0623683498fa15205b14

      Newman, D. J.; Cragg, G. M. Natural products as sources of new drugs from 1981 to 2014. J. Nat. Prod. 2016, 79, 629– 661,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jnatprod.5b01055
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Natural Products as Sources of New Drugs from 1981 to 2014
      Newman, David J.; Cragg, Gordon M.
      Journal of Natural Products (2016), 79 (3), 629-661CODEN: JNPRDF; ISSN:0163-3864. (American Chemical Society-American Society of Pharmacognosy)
      This contribution is a completely updated and expanded version of the four prior analogous reviews that were published in this journal in 1997, 2003, 2007, and 2012. In the case of all approved therapeutic agents, the time frame has been extended to cover the 34 years from Jan. 1, 1981, to Dec. 31, 2014, for all diseases worldwide, and from 1950 (earliest so far identified) to Dec. 2014 for all approved antitumor drugs worldwide. As mentioned in the 2012 review, we have continued to utilize our secondary subdivision of a "natural product mimic", or "NM", to join the original primary divisions and the designation "natural product botanical", or "NB", to cover those botanical "defined mixts." now recognized as drug entities by the U.S. FDA (and similar organizations). From the data presented in this review, the utilization of natural products and/or their novel structures, in order to discover and develop the final drug entity, is still alive and well. For example, in the area of cancer, over the time frame from around the 1940s to the end of 2014, of the 175 small mols. approved, 131, or 75%, are other than "S" (synthetic), with 85, or 49%, actually being either natural products or directly derived therefrom. In other areas, the influence of natural product structures is quite marked, with, as expected from prior information, the anti-infective area being dependent on natural products and their structures. We wish to draw the attention of readers to the rapidly evolving recognition that a significant no. of natural product drugs/leads are actually produced by microbes and/or microbial interactions with the "host from whence it was isolated", and therefore it is considered that this area of natural product research should be expanded significantly.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xit1Kqu7k%253D&md5=c9f2a44ab6b66331b7ef6ca64029328a

      Rodrigues, T.; Reker, D.; Schneider, P.; Schneider, G. Counting on natural products for drug design. Nat. Chem. 2016, 8, 531– 541,  DOI: 10.1038/nchem.2479
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Counting on natural products for drug design
      Rodrigues, Tiago; Reker, Daniel; Schneider, Petra; Schneider, Gisbert
      Nature Chemistry (2016), 8 (6), 531-541CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Natural products and their mol. frameworks have a long tradition as valuable starting points for medicinal chem. and drug discovery. Recently, there has been a revitalization of interest in the inclusion of these chemotypes in compd. collections for screening and achieving selective target modulation. Here the authors discuss natural-product-inspired drug discovery with a focus on recent advances in the design of synthetically tractable small mols. that mimic nature's chem. The authors highlight the potential of innovative computational tools in processing structurally complex natural products to predict their macromol. targets and attempt to forecast the role that natural-product-derived fragments and fragment-like natural products will play in next-generation drug discovery.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XmslSrsbk%253D&md5=3f6391192d648de2a54524afafd6203a
    9. 9
      Swinney, D. C.; Anthony, J. How were new medicines discovered?. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2011, 10, 507– 519,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd3480
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      How were new medicines discovered?
      Swinney, David C.; Anthony, Jason
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2011), 10 (7), 507-519CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Preclin. strategies that are used to identify potential drug candidates include target-based screening, phenotypic screening, modification of natural substances and biol.-based approaches. To investigate whether some strategies have been more successful than others in the discovery of new drugs, we analyzed the discovery strategies and the mol. mechanism of action (MMOA) for new mol. entities and new biologics that were approved by the US Food and Drug Administration between 1999 and 2008. Out of the 259 agents that were approved, 75 were first-in-class drugs with new MMOAs, and out of these, 50 (67%) were small mols. and 25 (33%) were biologics. The results also show that the contribution of phenotypic screening to the discovery of first-in-class small-mol. drugs exceeded that of target-based approaches - with 28 and 17 of these drugs coming from the two approaches, resp. - in an era in which the major focus was on target-based approaches. We postulate that a target-centric approach for first-in-class drugs, without consideration of an optimal MMOA, may contribute to the current high attrition rates and low productivity in pharmaceutical research and development.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXotlCmsbs%253D&md5=7503620f8fbadb0a829f6ea2029936a2
    10. 10
      Bebbington, M. W. P. Natural product analogues: towards a blueprint for analogue-focused synthesis. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2017, 46, 5059– 5109,  DOI: 10.1039/C6CS00842A
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Natural product analogues: towards a blueprint for analogue-focused synthesis
      Bebbington, Magnus W. P.
      Chemical Society Reviews (2017), 46 (16), 5059-5109CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      For the first time a general overview of approaches to the synthesis of natural product analogs is presented. This reflects a process of evolution of natural product synthesis which has accelerated in the years since the implementation of diversity-oriented synthesis, which has emerged in parallel with collective synthesis, diverted total synthesis and the prepn. of truncated natural products optimized for biol. activity. A method involving computational assessment for the validation of core-modified natural product analogs is discussed.

      Prior, M.; Chiruta, C.; Currais, A.; Goldberg, J.; Ramsey, J.; Dargusch, R.; Maher, P. A.; Schubert, D. Back to the future with phenotypic screening. ACS Chem. Neurosci. 2014, 5, 503– 513,  DOI: 10.1021/cn500051h
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      Back to the Future with Phenotypic Screening
      Prior, Marguerite; Chiruta, Chandramouli; Currais, Antonio; Goldberg, Josh; Ramsey, Justin; Dargusch, Richard; Maher, Pamela A.; Schubert, David
      ACS Chemical Neuroscience (2014), 5 (7), 503-513CODEN: ACNCDM; ISSN:1948-7193. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. There are no disease-modifying drugs for any old age assocd. neurodegenerative disease or stroke. This is at least in part due to the failure of drug developers to recognize that the vast majority of neurodegenerative diseases arise from a confluence of multiple toxic insults that accumulate during normal aging and interact with genetic and environmental risk factors. Thus, it is unlikely that the current single target approach based upon rare dominant mutations or even a few preselected targets is going to yield useful drugs for these conditions. Therefore, the identification of drug candidates for neurodegeneration should be based upon their efficacy in phenotypic screening assays that reflect the biol. of the aging brain, not a single, preselected target. It is argued here that this approach to drug discovery is the most likely to produce safe and effective drugs for neurodegenerative diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXosVWjtbY%253D&md5=9d00b537d71aa7bef15fc73d784aba95
    15. 15
      Gates, M.; Tschudi, G. The synthesis of morphine. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1956, 78, 1380– 1393,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01588a033
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Synthesis of morphine
      Gates, Marshall; Tschudi, Gilg
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1956), 78 (), 1380-93CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      The completion of the 1st synthesis of morphine is described. The yield of 3,4-dimethoxy-9,10-dioxo-4b-cyanomethyl-4a,4b,5,8,9,10-hexahydrophenanthrene (I), m. 238-40°, prepd. by the method described previously (C.A. 45, 1089c), was raised to 66% by the use of purified dioxane instead of AcOH as solvent, heating for 3 days, and using (cyanomethyl)quinone recrystd. from Me2CO. I (1.00 g.) hydrogenated 4 hrs. at 27 atm. pressure in 20 cc. abs. EtOH over 200 mg. Cu chromite catalyst at 124-31°, the cooled mixt. dild. with C6H6, filtered with celite, washed with 10% NaOH, 1% HCl, and H2O, dried, concd., and the residue recrystd. gave 504 g. oxo lactam (II) (R = H), colorless small prisms, m. 264-6° (all m.ps. cor.), readily sol. in 12N HCl and repptd. unchanged on diln. The 6-Cl deriv. of I (586 mg.) gave similarly 83 mg. II (R = Cl), m. 268-9°, sol. in 12N HCl and repptd. on diln. II (801 mg.) added to 4.5 g. KOH pellets and 8 cc. 100% N2H4.H2O at 155°, the mixt. heated 1 hr. at 155°, cooled, and dild. with 4 vols. H2O gave 703 mg. lactam (III), m. 209.5-11°, felty needles from cold C6H6 and prisms from hot C6H6. If the reduction of II is carried out similarly at 200-10°, a mono-Me ether, C17H19NO3, m. 283-6° (uncor.), is obtained; this was readily remethylated with Me2SO4 and alkali to III; the crude reaction mixt. remethylated yielded 56% III. III (150 mg.) in 50 cc. PhMe concd. to 25 cc. by boiling, treated with 15 mg. NaH, refluxed 135 min., treated with 1 cc. MeI, the mixt. refluxed 1 hr., cooled, washed, and concd. gave 131 mg. N-Me deriv. (IV) of III, m. 227-9° (from C6H6), sol. in 12N HCl, repptd. unchanged on diln. III (505 mg.) in 40 cc. PhMe concd. to about 20 cc. by boiling, refluxed 2 hrs. with 45 mg. NaOH, cooled, treated with 1 cc. MeI, refluxed 1 hr., concd. to about 10 cc., dild. with 12 cc. dry Et2O, treated with 15 cc. N LiAlH4 in Et2O, refluxed 48 hrs., decompd. with EtOAc, treated with dil. HCl, the org. layer extd. with dil. HCl contg. a little NaHSO3, the combined aq. layer and ext. slowly run into excess strong aq. KOH contg. Rochelle salt, extd. with Et2O, the ext. dried, evapd., heated in vacuo at 100°, and the residual viscous oil dissolved in a small amt. of MeOH and treated with 425 mg. picric acid in MeOH yielded 780 mg. picrate (V) of racemic β-Δ6-dihydrodeoxycodeine Me ether (VI), bright yellow crystals, m. 199.5-200.5° (decompn.). IV reduced similarly with LiAlH4 gave 82% V. V (280 mg.) partitioned between dil. aq. LiOH and Et2O, and the Et2O layer washed, dried, and evapd. yielded 156 mg. VI, large colorless plates or leaves m. 84-5° (from MeOH). VI (11 mg.) treated with 14 mg. racemic dibenzoyltartaric acid in MeOH gave the racemic dibenzoyl tartrate (VII), m. 184-4.2° (from MeOH-CHCl3). Racemic VI (120 mg.) in MeOH treated with 159 mg. dibenzoyl-L(+)-tartaric acid in MeOH yielded 111 mg. dibenzoyl-L(+)-tartrate (VIII) of d-VI, colorless prisms, m. 162-3.5° (from MeOH), [α]D27 44.5° (c 1.53, CHCl3). VIII (57 mg.) in H2O treated with excess dil. NH4OH gave 22 mg. d-VI, m. 43.5-4.5° (from pentane), [α]D27 80° (c 1.24, EtOH), also obtainable in a modification, m. 57.5-58°. d-VI and MeI gave d-VI.MeI, m. 186.5-88° (from MeOH-EtOAc). d-VI gave the picrate, m. 230-1.5° (decompn.). The MeOH filtrates from the crystn. of the VIII concd. to dryness, treated with dil. NH4OH, allowed to stand overnight, the viscous oil washed with H2O by decantation twice, dried, dissolved in MeOH, and the soln. treated with 82 mg. dibenzoyl-D(-)-tartaric acid yielded 70 mg. dibenzoyl-D(-)-tartrate (IX) of l-VI, m. 161.5-62°, [α]D27 -44° (c 1.94, CHCl3). IX (116 mg.) in H2O basified with NH4OH and triturated gave 48 mg. l-VI, m. 55.5-57° (from MeOH), [α]D27 -79° (c 1.09, EtOH); picrate, m. 228.5-30°. The picrates of l-VI and d-VI (2.15 mg. each) crystd. from CHCl3-MeOH gave V, m. 210-12°. β-Thebainone (X) HClO4 salt (50 mg.), m. 150-3° (evacuated tube), in 1.5 l. EtOH hydrogenated under ambient conditions 45 min. over 500 mg. PtO2, the mixt. acidified with 20 cc. concd. HCl, hydrogenated 50-60 hrs., filtered, the filtrate concd., filtered from the cryst. deposit, the filtrate evapd. to dryness on the steam bath in an air stream, the combined residues suspended in 10% aq. NaOH contg. some Na2S2O4, and the insol. portion washed with H2O and resuspended in 10% aq. NaOH left 2.5 g. β-tetrahydrodeoxycodeine (XI) hemihydrate, m. 140-52° with sintering at 126° (from EtOAc), [α]D29 -40° (c 1.24, CHCl3); XI.HI, m. 259-61° (decompn.); XI.MeI.H2O, m. 160-4° with softening at 150° (from MeOH-EtOAc); XI picrate, m. 233-4° (decompn.). The combined alk. filtrates from the XI carbonated to excess, extd. with CHCl3, and the ext. worked up yielded 19.2 g. β-dihydrothebainol (XII), m. 165.5-66°, [α]D30 -23° (c 0.920, EtOH); 2nd crop, 1.5 g. XII.MeI, m. 264-5° (from MeOH-EtOAc). β-Dihydrothebainone (XIIa) (6.18 g.) [purified through the HClO4 salt, m. 262-4° (decompn.)] methylated with PhNMe3OEt gave 6.31 g. alkali-insol. redbrown glass which, distd. in a mol. still at 10-2 mm. at 220-30°, yielded 5.55 g. Me ether (XIII) of XIIa, m. 122-3°, [α]D27 -51.4° (c 2.49, EtOH) (from cyclohexane); picrate, m. 249-50° (decompn.) (from CHCl3-MeOH); semicarbazone-O.5EtOH, colorless cottony needles, m. 202.5-204° (with gas evolution). XIII (132 mg.) in 4 cc. dry Et2O treated with 2 cc. 0.56M LiAlH4 in Et2O, the mixt. allowed to stand 1 hr., decompd. with EtOAc, then with excess dil. HCl, the clear acid soln. run into excess aq. KOH contg. Rochelle salt, the sepd. oily base worked up with CHCl3, and the crude material treated with picric acid gave a picrate, m. 181-3°; the crude material treated with hot cyclohexane and seeded gave 45 mg. Me ether (XIV) of XII, prisms, m. 152-4°; the combined filtrates concd., and the residue treated with MeOH and 70 mg. picric acid yielded 63 mg. picrate (XV) of the C6-epimer (XVI) of XIV, prisms, m. 224.5-26° (decompn.). XV (259 mg.) partitioned between dil. aq. LiOH and CHCl3, and the CHCl3 layer worked up gave 159 mg. pale yellow glass which, distd. at 10-2 mm. and 160-200° bath temp., gave a noncrystallizable colorless distillate of XVI, [α]D27 -19° (c 2.25, EtOH); XVI.MeI, m. 146-51° with gas evolution (from EtOAc-MeOH). PhNMe2-p-MeC6H4SO3Me-adduct (17.5 g.) in 40 cc. warm abs. EtOH added to 1.4 g. Na in 20 cc. warm abs. EtOH, the ppt. filtered off, washed with abs. EtOH, the combined filtrates treated with 13.0 g. XII, the EtOH removed in vacuo, the dark residue heated 1.5 hrs. at 130°, cooled, dissolved in 15% AcOH, steam-distd. to remove the PhNMe2, basified with 20% KOH, extd. with CHCl3, and the ext. washed, dried, and evapd gave 10.3 g. XIV, m. 153-5°, [α]D27 -22° (c 2.50, EtOH); XIV.MeI, small colorless prisms, m. 243-5° (from EtOAc-MeOH); XIV picrate, 2 polymorphic forms, m. 190-1°, 221-2.5°. XIV (10.3 g.), m. 149-51°, in 95 cc. dry pyridine kept 5.5 days with 12.5 g. p-MeC6H4SO2Cl, cooled, dild. with 20 cc. H2O, allowed to stand 2 hrs., dild. with ice water, just basified with aq. Na2CO3, extd. with Et2O, and the ext. worked up yielded 16.4 g. p-toluenesulfonate (XVII) of XIV, colorless needles, m. 133-3.5° (from EtOAc-Et2O). Crude XVII (16.4 g.) refluxed 2 hrs. in s-collidine, cooled, dild. with Et2O, washed with dil. aq. Na2CO3 and H2O, evapd., the residue steamdistd. to remove the collidine, dild. with Et2O, sepd. from a small aq. layer (which was extd. with Et2O), evapd., and the thick colorless oily residue (9.8 g.) chromatographed on 550 g. Al2O3 gave 5.30 g. crude d-VI, m. 54-6°, and 4.35 g. crude Δ5-isomer (XVIII) of d-VI, partially cryst. Each crude material purified through the picrates yielded 8.55 g. picrate (XIX) of d-VI, m. 230-2° (decompn.), and 4.60 g. crude picrate of XVIII, m. 225.5-6.5° (decompn.). XIX partitioned between CHCl3 in aq. LiOH in the usual manner yielded 4.85 g. d-VI, m. 43.5-44° or 57.5-58°, both colorless needles from pentane, [α]D27 80° (c 1.55, EtOH). l-VI and d-VI (11 mg. each) combined and recrystd. from MeOH yielded 19 mg. VI, m. 82.5-84°. d-VI.MeI, m. 188-9° (from MeOH-EtOAc); VIII, m. 163-3.5°, [α]D27 48° (c 1.80, CHCl3). VIII (1.35 mg.) and 1.33 mg. XIII combined and recrystd. from MeOH gave VII, m. 184°. d-VI (50 mg.), m. 57-7.5°, hydrogenated in MeOH contg. AcOH over PtO2, filtered, concd., the residue dild. with Et2O, washed with excess dil. NH4OH and H2O, dried, concd., and the residue dissolved in a little MeOH and treated with 40 mg. picric acid in MeOH yielded 91 mg. picrate (XX) of the Me ether (XXI) of XI, m. 204-6° (from CHCl3-MeOH). XX (61 mg.) partitioned between Et2O and dil. LiOH gave 35 mg. XXI, colorless crystals, m. 36.5-7.5°, [α]D27 -18° (c 1.92, EtOH); XXI.MeI, m. 236-7° (from EtOAc-MeOH). The picrate of XVIII similarly treated yielded 2.60 g. XVIII, colorless prisms or plates, m. 78.5-79° (from pentane); XVIII.MeI, colorless plates or prisms, m. 227.5-29° (from MeOH-EtOAc); dibenzoyl-L(+)-tartrate of XVIII, m. 166-6.5° (from MeOH). XVIII hydrogenated in the usual manner yielded XXI, m. 36.5-7.5°; XXI picrate, m. 201-2°; XXI.MeI, m. 235-6°. XII (2.11 g.), m. 163-6°, in 25 cc. abs. EtOH treated with CH2N2 from 9.0 g. H2NCON(NO)Me (XXII), kept 23 hrs. at room temp., evapd. to dryness, the residue dissolved in 1:1 C6H6-hexane soln., extd. with Claisen alkali, washed, dried, concd., and the residual orange viscous oil or glass (1.66 g.) treated in Me2CO with HBr gave the cis isomer (XXIII).HBr of XIV.HBr, m. 254.5-55° (from Me2CO-MeOH), [α]D28 34° (c 0.44, EtOH). XXIII.HBr partitioned between aq. Na2CO3 and Et2O gave noncrystallizable XXIII, [α]D27 -28.4° (c 1.52, EtOH); XXIII.MeI, colorless fine needles, m. 279-81° (from MeOH). XXIII (0.69 g.) in 8 cc. dry pyridine kept 4.5 days at room temp. with 1.00 g. p-MeC6H4SO2Cl, and the mixt. worked up in the usual manner gave 0.95 g. p-toluenesulfonate (XXIV) (ring II/III cis) of XXIII, sheaves or prismatic needles, m. 165-6° (from Me2CO-EtOAc). Crude XXIV (0.90 g.) refluxed 2.5 hrs. in l0 cc. collidine, cooled, dild. with Et2O, washed with aq. Na2CO3, steam-distd., the residue dissolved in 1% HCl, washed with Et2O, basified with Na2CO3, extd. with CHCl3, the ext. worked up, and the residue distd. at 0.001 mm. and 140-80° yielded 0.47 g. Δ5(or 6)-dihydrodeoxycodeine Me ether (XXV), nearly colorless viscous oil. XXV (48 mg.) in a very small amt. of MeOH treated with 35 mg. fumaric acid and dild. with abs. Et2O yielded 74 mg. fumarate (XXVI) of XXV, m. 233-5° with gas evolution (from MeOH-Et2O). XXVI (92 mg.) partitioned between aq. Na2CO3 and Et2O yielded 57 mg. XXV, colorless, very viscous oil; XXV.MeI, m. 251.5-2.5° (from Me2CO-EtOAc). XXV (598 mg.) and 244 mg. BzOH in 14 cc. CHCl3 treated 3 hrs. with 10.6 cc. 0.583M BzO2H in CHCl3, the mixt. extd. with aq. Na2CO3, then with aq. Na2S2O4, dried, evapd., and the residue triturated with cyclohexane yielded 503 mg. epoxide (XXVIa) of XXV, amorphous solid, m. 80-170°; the cyclohexane filtrate concd. gave 180 mg. yellow glass which yielded 128 mg. picrate (XXVII) of XXVIa, small bright yellow prisms, m. 198.5-200°. XXVII (100 mg.) partitioned between CHCl3 and aq. dil. LiOH yielded 57 mg. XXVIa, m. 92-3.4°. The crude, cyclohexane-insol. XXVIa hydrogenated catalytically yielded 34% XXVII, and thus probably contained the corresponding N-oxide. The crude total XXVIa from 200 mg. XXV in dry Et2O kept 2 days at room temp. with 4 cc. 0.95M LiAlH4, decompd. with HCl, the aq. acidic layer added dropwise to strong aq. KOH contg. Rochelle salt, extd. with CHCl3, the ext. worked up, and the residual oil (120 mg.) chromatographed on 30 g. Al2O3 gave 55 mg. material which with 42 mg. picric acid in MeOH yielded 51 mg. picrate, m. 198-200° (decompn.); the picrate partitioned between dil. aq. LiOH and Et2O gave 14.5 mg. 7-HO deriv. (XXVIII) of XXI, heavy prisms, m. 141-2° (from EtOAc); XXVIII.MeI, m. 262-3.5° (from EtOAc-MeOH); XXVIII picrate, m. 218-19° (decompn.) (from MeOH). XXV (89 mg.) in 1 cc. C6H6 treated with 1.6 cc. 0.198M OsO4 in C6H6 1.5 hrs. at room temp., the ppt. centrifuged, washed with C6H6, warmed on the steam bath with aq. Na2SO3 and Na2HPO4, filtered, the black residue washed with MeOH, the combined filtrates basified with NH4OH, extd. with CHCl3, and the ext. worked up gave 71 mg. pale yellow glass, which with 50 mg. picric acid in MeOH yielded 54 mg. picrate (XXIX) of cis-6,7-dihydroxy-β-tetrahydrodeoxycodeine Me ether (XXX), bright yellow needles, m. 226-7° (decompn.) (from MeOH-CHCl3). XXIX (63 mg.) partitioned between aq. LiOH and CHCl3 yielded 39 mg. XXX, colorless plates, m. 151-2° (from EtOAc). XXV (382 mg.) in 6 cc. 98% HCO2H treated 40 hrs. at room temp. with 0.20 cc. 30% H2O2, dild. with H2O, basified with 10% aq. NaOH, extd. with CHCl3, the ext. worked up, the residue dissolved in NaOH in MeOH, the MeOH removed, the residue partitioned between CHCl3 and H2O, and the CHCl3 layer worked up gave 302 mg. transisomer (XXXI) of XXX, colorless needles, m. 201-2°; picrate, m. 245-6.5° (decompn.) (from MeOH). XXVIa in MeOH hydrogenated gave the mono-Me ether of XXXI, m. 174.5-5.5°, large prisms from EtOAc, as a by-product. XXV (208 mg.) in 18 cc. 18% H2SO4 heated 5 days under N on the steam bath, dild. with H2O, basified with aq. KOH, extd. with CHCl3, and the ext. worked up yielded 228 mg. very viscous oil or glass which, chromatographed on 13 g. Al2O3, gave 110 mg. crude XXV (identified as VIII, 216 mg., m. 163.5-65°), an intermediate fraction which, rechromatographed and processed through its picrate [21 mg., m. 214-16.5° (decompn.)], yielded 7 mg. XXVIII, m. 140-1° [XXVIII.MeI, m. 262-3.5°], and 58 mg. XIV, stout colorless prisms, [α]D28 -23° (c 2.78, EtOH), m. 151-3.5° [XIV.MeI, m. 243-4°]; in some runs small amts. of XVI were recovered as its picrate, m. 216-22°. VI (98.5 mg.) gave similarly 28% dl-XIV, colorless small prisms, m. 149-50.5°. The hydration of VI gave small amts. of dl-XXVIII, fine colorless prismatic needles or blades, m. 172.5-3.5°. XIV (300 mg.), m. 153-4°, 10 cc. (HOCH2-CH2)2O, 12 pellets KOH, and 0.2 cc. N2H4.H2O heated 1.25 hrs. under N at 221-7° (the mixt. blown with N during the 1st 5 min.), cooled, dild. with H2O contg. a little Na2S2O4, carbonated to excess, extd. with CHCl3, and the ext. worked up gave 186 mg. slowly crystg. residue; the aq. layer extd. with BuOH, the ext. worked up, the residue in MeOH treated overnight with CH2N2 in Et2O (from 1 g. XXII), the mixt. evapd., the residue partitioned between CHCl3 and dil. NH4OH, the CHCl3 layer worked up, and the residue (90 mg.) chromatographed on 15 g. Al2O3 gave 97 mg. XIV, m. 152.5-54° (from EtOAc), and 105 mg. XII, m. 165.5-66° (from EtOAc), [α]D28 -25° (c 1.06, EtOH) (sol. in alkali and repptd. by CO2) (XII.MeI, m. 266-8°). XVI (125 mg.) cleaved gave dl-XII, colorless leaves, m. 185-6°. XVI (204 mg.) and 247 mg. pyridine HCl salt heated 4 hrs. at 195-200°, cooled, dissolved in H2O, basified with KOH contg. Na2S2O4, and extd. with CHCl3, the aq. alk. layer carbonated to excess, extd. with BuOH, and the ext. worked up gave 72 mg. compd., C17H21NO2, small prisms, m. 258-62° (decompn.), [α]D28 46° (c 1.32, dioxane); it had lost both MeO groups and the OH group at C-6. K (380 mg.) in 7 cc. abs. Me3COH and 20 cc. dry C6H6 distd. with the addn. of more C6H6 until the b.p. of pure C6H6 was reached, the mixt. refluxed 10 min., treated with 400 mg. XII, m. 162-4°, and 3 g. Ph2CO in dry C6H6, refluxed 2.5 hrs., cooled, extd. with dil. HCl, the acid ext. washed with C6H6, basified with NH4OH, extd. with CHCl3, and the ext. worked up yielded 399 mg. light tan glassy residue which, dissolved in EtOH and treated with excess 25% HClO4, gave 450 mg. X.HClO4, m. 264-6° (decompn.) (from EtOH); 2nd crop, 25 mg. X.HClO4 partitioned between CHCl3 and dil. NH4OH gave X, m. 120.5-22° (from aq. MeOH), [α]D26 -47° (c 1.53, EtOH); oxime, m. 223-5° (decompn.). X (301 mg.) in 30 cc. 1:1 AcOH-dry Et2O contg. a few drops 4N HBr in AcOH treated with 3 cc. of a soln. of 1.60 g. Br in 10 cc. glacial AcOH, the mixt. kept 22 hrs. at room temp., dild. with H2O, just basified with dil. NH4OH, extd. with CHCl3, the ext. worked up, and the residue triturated with EtOAc gave 1,x,x-tribromo-β-dihydrothebainone (XXXII), small prisms, m. 219-21° (decompn.), [α]D25 -53.2° (c 3.18, CHCl3). XXXII (134 mg.) in AcOH hydrogenated over PtO2 gave the 1-Br deriv. (XXXIII) of XIIa, m. 172.5-74°, [α]D26 -32° (c 2.03, EtOH); XXXIII.HClO4, m. 272-6° (decompn.), [α]D25 -12° (c 1.25, 50% aq. EtOH); XXXIII 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone, m. 144-8° with gas evolution (from EtOAc-CHCl3). X.HClO4 (402 mg.) partitioned between NH4OH and CHCl3, the resulting free X dissolved in 10 cc. glacial AcOH, the soln. treated with 0.002 moles Br in 8 cc. glacial AcOH, kept 24 hrs. at room temp., treated with 220 mg. 2,4-(O2N)2C6H3NHNH2 (XXXIV), refluxed 5 min., cooled, basified with NH4OH, extd. with CHCl3, the ext. worked up, and the orange-red residue (704 mg.) chromatographed on 15 g. Al2O3 gave 229 mg. 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone (XXXV) of cis-1-bromothebainone (XXXVI), m. 207-8° (from EtOAc), [α]D27 -1307° (c 1.63, CHCl3), -1090° (c 0.800, Me2CO). Thebainone hemihydrate (103 mg.) and 70 mg. XXXIV in 3 cc. glacial AcOH heated 20 min. on the steam bath, cooled, treated with 100 mg. NaOAc, brominated 5 min. with 3.33 cc. soln. of 1.60 g. Br in 100 cc. AcOH, dild. with H2O, basified with NH4OH, extd. with CHCl3, and the ext. worked up gave 88 mg. XXXV, orange plates, m. 207-8°. β-Thebainone HClO4 salt converted to the 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone, m. 224-5°, and a 63-mg. portion in 1 cc. glacial AcOH contg. 15 mg. NaOAc brominated with 1.32 g. of a soln. of 1.60 g. Br in 100 cc. AcOH yielded 74 mg. 1-bromo-β-thebainone 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone (XXXVII), ruby-red prisms, m. 157-65° with gas evolution, [α]D27 -76.4° (c 1.57, CHCl3). XXXVII (34 mg.) heated 2.5 hrs. in 1 cc. glacial AcOH on the steam bath, dild., basified with NH4OH, extd. with CHCl3, and the ext. worked up yielded XXXV, orange-yellow plates, m. 206-7° (from EtOAc). XXXV (200 mg.) in 20 cc. Me2CO and 8 cc. 12N HCl refluxed 20 min., cooled, dild. with H2O, extd. with CHCl3, the ext. washed with dil. NH4OH, dried, concd. to 25 cc., evapd., and the residue partitioned between 30% AcOH and 1:1 C6H6-cyclohexane yielded 13 mg. XXXV, m. 203.5-205°, [α]D25 -1360° (c 0.0472, CHCl3); the aq. layer basified with NH4OH, extd. 4 times with CHCl3, and the ext. worked up gave 76 mg. XXXVI, small colorless needles, m. 198.5-9.5°, [α]D27 -85° (c 1.54, CHCl3), readily sol. in dil. alkalies with yellow color, also obtained by treating 31 mg. thebainone hemihydrate in 1 cc. AcOH with 1 cc. soln. of 1.60 g. Br in 100 cc. AcOH. XXXVI (298 mg.), m. 195-7°, in 10 cc. AcOH treated with 3 cc. AcOH contg. 0.79 millimole Br, then dropwise with 4N HBr in AcOH, dild. with H2O, just basified with NH4OH, extd. with CHCl3, and the residue from the ext. treated with Me2CO yielded 1.77 mg. 1,x-dibromothebainone (XXXVIII), m. 215-18° (decompn.) (from CHCl3-Me2CO); it did not give a ppt. with alc. AgNO3 and was unaltered by short boiling with collidine; it was slowly sol. in cold 15% aq. KOH and this soln. warmed deposited an amorphous solid. Thebainone hemihydrate (308 mg.) dibrominated gave 355 mg. XXXVIII (without added HBr in AcOH). XXXVI (174 mg.) in 15 cc. EtOH hydrogenated 11 min. over 21 mg. PtO2, the mixt. filtered, dild. with H2O, basified with NH4OH, and worked up with CHCl3 gave 191 mg. cis-1-bromodihydrothebainone (XXXIX), m. 99-115°, foaming, resolidifying, and remelting at 154-62°; purified through XXXIX.HI, colorless needles m. 206.5-8.5° (from H2O), crumbled on drying at 100°; XXXIX.HBr.2H2O, m. 202-6°, foaming 210-12°, loss of hydrate H2O at 140-60°, [α]D26 -48.6° (c 1.07, EtOH). XXXVI (96 mg.) in EtOH hydrogenated over 200 mg. Pd-BaCO3 yielded 74 mg. crude cis-XIIa.0.5H2O, m. 123-36°, converted to cis-XIIa.HI, m. 277-8.5°; XIIa.HI with dil. NH4OH gave cis-XIIa, heavy colorless prisms, m. 123-52°; oxime, m. 252-3.5°. XXXIX.HBr.2H2O (497 mg.) in 10 cc. glacial AcOH treated dropwise with swirling with 7 cc. glacial AcOH contg. 0.002 mole Br, kept 15 min. at room temp., treated with 220 mg. XXXIV, allowed to stand 1 hr., treated with 164 mg. NaOAc, allowed to stand 23 hrs., concd. to dryness in vacuo, the residue refluxed 0.5 hr. in 10 cc. purified pyridine, the pyridine removed in vacuo, the residue in CHCl3 washed with 10% aq. NaOH and H2O, dried, evapd., and the residue chromatographed with CHCl3 on 25 g. Al2O3 gave 276 mg. 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone (XL) of 1-bromocodeinone (XLI), orange prismatic needles, m. 224-5°, [α]D27 -1968° (c 0.064, CHCl3). XL (200 mg.) refluxed 20 min. with 20 cc. Me2CO and 12 cc. 12N HCl, dild. with H2O, extd. with CHCl3, the CHCl3 ext. worked up in the usual manner, the residue partitioned between 50% aq. AcOH and 1:1 C6H6-cyclohexane, and the acid layer processed yielded 32 mg. unchanged XL, m. 219-22°; the colorless acid soln. cooled with ice, treated with excess 10% aq. NaOH, extd. with Et2O, the ext. worked up, and the residue (48 mg.), m. 90-2°, moistened with EtOAc altered form and gave crystals of XLI, m. 185-95°; the low-melting form recrystd. from EtOAc yielded XLI, colorless needles, m. 201-2° (decompn.), [α]D26 -182.7° (c 1.42, CHCl3). 1-Bromocodeine (1.54 g.), m. 158-61°, oxidized by the method of Homeyer and De LaMater (C.A. 48, 13733a) yielded 1.00 g. pure XLI, m. 202.5-3.5°, [α]D25 -180.6° (c 1.30, CHCl2); 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone, m. 224-4.5° (from EtOAc). XLI (86.4 mg.) in 5 cc. EtOH hydrogenated over 15 mg. PtO2 yielded 19 mg. 1-bromodihydrocodeinone, m. 207.5-8.5° (from EtOAc) (chromatographed on 3.0 g. Al2O3). XLI (200 mg.), m. 202.5-3.5°, 0.5 g. LiAlH4, and 30 cc. tetrahydrofuran refluxed 46 hrs., treated with EtOAc, acidified with 2N HCl, extd. with Et2O, the acid layer added slowly to strong aq. KOH contg. Rochelle salt, extd. with CHCl3, and the ext. worked up gave 146 mg. colorless glass which was converted with HBr to 110 mg. codeine (XLII) HBr salt, m. 148-50°, resolidifying and remelting at 273-8°. XLII.HBr in warm H2O with NH4OH gave 70 mg. solid, m. 153-6°, which, recrystd. from aq. MeOH, yielded 59 mg. XLII, large prisms (hydrated), m. 156.5-58°, [α]D27 -137° (c 1.15, EtOH). XLII, demethylated by the method of Rapoport, et al. (C.A. 47, 590g), yielded 34% morphine, colorless needles, m. 254-6.4°, [α]D27 -126° (c 2.32, MeOH).
      >> More from SciFinder ®

    16. 16
      Gulland, J. M.; Robinson, R. CXII.-The morphine group. Part I. A discussion of the constitutional problem. J. Chem. Soc., Trans. 1923, 123, 980– 998,  DOI: 10.1039/CT9232300980
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Morphine group. I. Discussion of the constitutional formula
      Gulland, J. M.; Robinson, Robt.
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Transactions (1923), 123 (), 980-98CODEN: JCHTA3; ISSN:0368-1645.
      In this lengthy theoretical discussion a new formula (I) for codeine (morphine Me ether) is suggested, the main stages in the argument being: (a) Codeine is not unsatd. but contains a bridged ring. (b) The position of the bridge is deduced from (1) degradation of morphine or codeine to apomorphine and of codeine or thebaine to morphothebaine, (2) the relation of the morphine group to other opium alkaloids, (3) the consideration that in the decompns. leading to non-nitrogenous aromatic phenanthrene derivs. the breaking of a C-to-C union occurs because the point of attachment of the ethanamine chain offers a structural obstacle to the formation of aromatic nuclei. (c) The formula so deduced provides a natural explanation of the codeine →ψ-codeine transformation, the isomerization of α- and γ-methylmorphimethines, the production of methylmorphol, morphenol, morphothebaine, etc., in the course of various degradations. (d) Thebenine is regarded as owing its production from codeinone and ψ-codeinone to a mol. rearrangement analogous to that of isoborneol to camphene. A conceivable alternative constitutional formula (II) accommodating the conditions mentioned in (b, 3) is found to be not so satisfactory a summary of the chemistry of morphine and its derivs. as I, which is adopted. A fairly complete bibliography of morphine and derivs. is appended.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaB3sXhs1aluw%253D%253D&md5=b96a0b8d9cd7c9b413243790ab4005e4
    17. 17
      Naranjo, C. Ayahuasca, caapi, yage. Psychotropic properties of the harmala alkaloids. Psychopharmacol. Bull. 1967, 4, 16– 17
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      Ayahuasca, caapi, yage. Psychotropic properties of the harmala alkaloids
      Naranjo C
      Psychopharmacology bulletin (1967), 4 (3), 16-7 ISSN:0048-5764.
      There is no expanded citation for this reference.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaF1M3gt1KgsA%253D%253D&md5=12c539653023130c06a0093357e5905c
    18. 18
      Perkin, W. H.; Robinson, R. LXXIX.-Harmine and harmaline. Part III. J. Chem. Soc., Trans. 1919, 115, 933– 967,  DOI: 10.1039/CT9191500933
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Harmine and harmaline. III, IV
      Perkin, William Henry, Jr.; Robinson, Robert
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Transactions (1919), 115 (), 933-67,967-72CODEN: JCHTA3; ISSN:0368-1645.
      cf. C. A. 7, 592; 8, 909, 1116. As a result of further examn. of derivs. of harmine (A) and harmaline (B) the earlier views of structure are discarded in favor of the new formulas (I) and (II) for A, which differ only in the position of the Me group and, therefore, lead directly to the formula for norharmine (III) and formulas IV and V for B. Formula I is given preference over H because of the analogy to corydaline and formula IV is preferred to V because of (a) optical inactivity in the natural substance (V has an asym. C atom); (b) methochloride salts are quaternary salts and give no ppt. with NH3 in aq. solns.; (c) B forms additive products with NH2OH and HCN which can be explained by the ketimino-type of structure; the oxidation of tetrahydroharmine to form B is more readily explained with formula IV; on the other hand formula V explains better the formation of an Ac deriv., the N-methyl deriv., and the condensation with diazonium salts. Harmine methosulfate, C13H12ON2.Me2SO4 (C), is prepd. by rubbing 1 g. A into a paste with 1 cc. Me2SO4; after 24 hrs. the product is recrystd. from MeOH; m. 220°, readily sol. in hot H2O or MeOH, NaOH ppts. the hydrated ammonium hydroxide. The methiodide (D) is prepd. by adding 5 g. KI to 5 g. C in 150 cc. hot H2O; the pptd. product is recrystd. from alc.; m. 305-7°. When D is ground into a paste and digested with AgCl on a steam-bath, the methochloride (E) is formed, m. 305°, slightly sol. in hot MeOH; the aq. soln. fluoresces blue and resembles C in its behavior with NH3 and NaOH. Methylharmine (F) is prepd. by the action of NaOH on an aq. soln. of C or E; recrystd. from H2O it forms crystals with 2 H2O which are dehydrated by heating to 100°; the anhydrous substance m. 209°; it did not form a carbonate on exposure to the air; the freshly prepd. hydrate on treatment with dil. HCl yields the hydrochloride; recrystd. from dil. HCl, m. 305° (decompn.) and is identical with E. Methylkarmine methosulfate (G) prepd. like C can be recrystd. from H2O or MeOH; these solns. exhibit blue fluorescence; when 1 drop H2SO4 is added to an AcOH soln. a yellow liquid with green fluorescence is obtained; KOH with continued boiling probably produces the corresponding ammonium hydroxide which yields the methochloride (H) on treatment with HCl, m. 280-5°. Harmine methohydroxide sulfonic anhydride (I) is obtained in 100% yield when 5 g. A, 20 cc. PhMe, 15 cc. Me2SO4 and 10 cc. H2SO4 are heated for 0.5 hr., pptd. with H2O, the ppt. dissolved in dil. NaOH, filtered and the filtrate acidified with HCl. I is slightly sol. in org. solvents and readily sol. in aq. NaOH. On continued boiling with dil. HCl F is formed; boiling glycerol hydrolyzed I to form A. Methylnorharmine (J) was prepd. by adding 5 cc. Me2SO4 to a boiling PhH soln. of 2 g. norharmine (cf. C. A. 7, 592); the oil which seps. is allowed to cryst., washed with Et2O and then dissolved in H2O, from which it is pptd. with NaOH, filtered and after thorough drying recrystd. from PhH; m. 195-6°, readily sol. in EtOH, slightly sol. in PhH; from H2O it crystallizes as the methohydroxide; solns. of J show fluorescence similar to F. Harmaline methosulfate, (K) prepd. from B and Me2SO4 in PhH soln. is recrystd. from MeOH; m. 170-2°, readily sol. in H2O or EtOH; aq. NaOH converts K into methylharmine (cf. C. A. 8, 1116). The methiodide is best prepd. from K and KI in boiling H2O soln. Harmaline methochloride (L) prepd. like E is readily sol. in hot H2O or AcOH, slightly sol. in EtOH and insol. in Me2CO; m. 278° (decompn.); the aq. soln. is not pptd. by NH3; NaOH probably converts L into F. KMnO4 solns. are decolorized by L. When heated with concd. H2SO4 it is converted into harmaline methohydroxide sulfonic anhydride (M), which does not melt when heated to 300°; M is sol. in NaOH, from which it is again pptd. by HCl. A dil. H2SO4 soln. of K (3 g.) was reduced with 3% Na-Hg (200 g.) and the filtered soln. after addition of NaOH pptd. a gummy mass which after hardening was recrystd. with MeOH; this compd. m. 174-6° and is identical with methyldihydroharmaline (N) (cf. C. A. 8,1116). It is better to prep. N by reduction of L with Na-Hg in HCl soln. Me2SO4 in PhH soln. converts N into the methosulfate (O) which is recrystd. from MeOH; m. 188°; monoclinic crystals a:b = 0.738, β = 96° 55'. The methohydroxide methyl ether (P) of N, which is probably identical with the product obtained by the action of MeI on N by decompn. with MeOH-NaOH, is prepd. by boiling O with 10% MeOH-KOH, evapg. the MeOH under reduced presure and adding H2O; recrystd. from Et2O or from a mixt. of PhH and light petroleum; repeated analyses for C, H and N, MeO by Zeisel's method gave values for C16H24O2N2 (cf. C. A. 8, 1116); m. 128-9°; readily sol. in alc., Me2CO or in H2O, Et2O or petroleum ether; isomethyltetrahydroharmine methohydroxide ethyl ether (Q) was prepd. by digesting for 1 hr. 1 g. O with alc. KOH (10 cc. of 20% soln.) and pptg. with H2O; the ppt. was dissolved in Et2O and the solvent evapd.; attempts to recryst. Q were not successful; Q on treatment with HCl or HI yields the hydrochloride (R) or hydriodide (S) identical with those from P. R is sol. in H2O and slightly sol. in dil. HCl; S m. 290-5° (decompn.). Dehydroisomethyltetrahydroharmine methohydroxide (T) is obtained on treatment of S with dil. NH4OH and redigested with NH4OH until all iodine is removed; it does not melt below 300°; is readily sol. in MeOH and is repptd. by Et2O; boiling with dil. HCl converts it into a hydrochloride. P on treatment with Me2SO4 in PhH soln. yields a methosulfate (U) of the dehydro base which reacts with KI in H2O soln. to form the methiodide (V), m. 290-2° (decompn.). When U is boiled with MeOH-KOH, Me3N is eliminated and a milky liquid is produced which gradually deposits a viscid ppt. almost insol. in org. solvents, resembling rubber in many properties; it is probably a polymeric divinyl deriv. Ketoisonormethyltetra-hydroharmine (W) is formed when N is oxidized with KMnO4 in Me2CO soln.; recrystd. from Me2CO lemon-yellow needles, m. 228°, are obtained; insol. in dil. mineral acids and H2O ppts. it from AcOH soln.; insol. in aq. alkalies; expts. show that it is not readily acted upon by phosphoryl chloride. W is also formed on oxidation of K. Tetrahydroharmine (Y), m. 199°, may be readily prepd. by reduction of B in HCl soln. with Na amalgam; the hydrochloride thus obtained is dissolved in hot H2O and the base which ppts. on addition of NH4OH is recrystd. from MeOH; 90% yield; on oxidation with KMnO4 in Me2CO it is again converted into B. On treatment of Y with Me2SO4 in PhH, methyltetrahydroharmine (Z) is obtained; colorless needles, m. 174-6°, from PhH and then from MeOH. A, C, F, G, the sulfonic acid of F, norharmine and methylnorharmine do not react with PhN2Cl, p-NO2C6H4N2Cl, nor PhN2C6H4SO3H in aq. acid, alkaline or neutral soln. The condensation products from B and L with p-NO2C6H4N2Cl in dil. AcOH in presence of NaOAc were prepd. p-Nitrobenzeneazotetrahydroharmine, m. 173-5°; benzeneazotetrahydroharminesulfonic acid, and benzeneazomethyltetrahydroharminesulfonic acid were also prepd. W does not condense with diazonium salts. Harmol (a) was prepd. in almost theoretical yield by boiling A with excess HI (1.7) during 4 hrs.; the excess I was removed with H2SO3 and the product pptd. by H2O was dissolved in dil. NaOH; the filtered soln. was acidified with AcOH and a pptd. with NH4OH. a may be converted into harman (b) by distn. with Zn in H; b crysts. from PhH; from dil. H2SO4 as a sulfate and from dil. HCl containing HgCl2 as the mercurichloride; b is identical with the base C12H10N2 prepd. by Hopkins and Cole (J. Physiol. 29, 451 (1903)) by oxidation of tryptophan with FeCl3. This seems to confirm the theory that A originates in nature from hydroxytryptophan and is worthy of investigation since it is probably on similar lines to the vital synthesis of an alkaloid. Since the benzene-pyrrole-pyridine nucleus which this work indicates as contained in the mol. of harmine does not find a place in any approved system of nomenclature, the name carboline for the structure and the following scheme of numbering is suggested: Thus harmine is 11-methoxy-3-methyl-4-carboline.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaC1MXhsFynuw%253D%253D&md5=aa235ec432c5ffedc2f51ff6a0076d82
    19. 19
      Morales-Garcia, J. A.; de la Fuente Revenga, M.; Alonso-Gil, S.; Rodriguez-Franco, M. I.; Feilding, A.; Perez-Castillo, A.; Riba, J. The alkaloids of Banisteriopsis caapi, the plant source of the Amazonian hallucinogen Ayahuasca, stimulate adult neurogenesis in vitro. Sci. Rep. 2017, 7, 5309,  DOI: 10.1038/s41598-017-05407-9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      The alkaloids of Banisteriopsis caapi, the plant source of the Amazonian hallucinogen Ayahuasca, stimulate adult neurogenesis in vitro
      Morales-Garcia Jose A; Alonso-Gil Sandra; Perez-Castillo Ana; Morales-Garcia Jose A; Alonso-Gil Sandra; Perez-Castillo Ana; Morales-Garcia Jose A; de la Fuente Revenga Mario; Riba Jordi; de la Fuente Revenga Mario; Rodriguez-Franco Maria Isabel; de la Fuente Revenga Mario; Feilding Amanda; Riba Jordi
      Scientific reports (2017), 7 (1), 5309 ISSN:.
      Banisteriopsis caapi is the basic ingredient of ayahuasca, a psychotropic plant tea used in the Amazon for ritual and medicinal purposes, and by interested individuals worldwide. Animal studies and recent clinical research suggests that B. caapi preparations show antidepressant activity, a therapeutic effect that has been linked to hippocampal neurogenesis. Here we report that harmine, tetrahydroharmine and harmaline, the three main alkaloids present in B. caapi, and the harmine metabolite harmol, stimulate adult neurogenesis in vitro. In neurospheres prepared from progenitor cells obtained from the subventricular and the subgranular zones of adult mice brains, all compounds stimulated neural stem cell proliferation, migration, and differentiation into adult neurons. These findings suggest that modulation of brain plasticity could be a major contribution to the antidepressant effects of ayahuasca. They also expand the potential application of B. caapi alkaloids to other brain disorders that may benefit from stimulation of endogenous neural precursor niches.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1cjnsVWqsA%253D%253D&md5=2db32bd110143a5dad23bfb7471ee5f5

    29. 29
      Benowitz, N. L.; Hukkanen, J.; Jacob, P., 3rd Nicotine chemistry, metabolism, kinetics and biomarkers. Handb. Exp. Pharmacol. 2009, 192, 29– 60,  DOI: 10.1007/978-3-540-69248-5_2
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29
      Nicotine Chemistry, Metabolism, Kinetics and Biomarkers
      Benowitz, Neal L.; Hukkanen, Janne; Jacob, Peyton, III
      Handbook of Experimental Pharmacology (2009), 192 (Nicotine Psychopharmacology), 29-60CODEN: HEPHD2; ISSN:0171-2004. (Springer GmbH)
      Nicotine underlies tobacco addiction, influences tobacco use patterns, and is used as a pharmacol. aid to smoking cessation. The absorption, distribution and disposition characteristics of nicotine from tobacco and medicinal products are reviewed. Nicotine is metabolized primarily by the liver enzymes CYP2A6, UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT), and flavin-contg. monooxygenase (FMO). In addn. to genetic factors, nicotine metab. is influenced by diet and meals, age, sex, use of estrogen-contg. hormone prepns., pregnancy and kidney disease, other medications, and smoking itself. Substantial racial/ethnic differences are obsd. in nicotine metab., which are likely influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. The most widely used biomarker of nicotine intake is cotinine, which may be measured in blood, urine, saliva, hair, or nails. The current optimal plasma cotinine cut-point to distinguish smokers from non-smokers in the general US population is 3 ng ml-1. This cut-point is much lower than that established 20 years ago, reflecting less secondhand smoke exposure due to clear air policies and more light or occasional smoking.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtVKlurbK&md5=68e787f524dd7b7fadc7bc75d24034e2

      Leonard, E.; Runguphan, W.; O’Connor, S.; Prather, K. J. Opportunities in metabolic engineering to facilitate scalable alkaloid production. Nat. Chem. Biol. 2009, 5, 292– 300,  DOI: 10.1038/nchembio.160
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32
      Opportunities in metabolic engineering to facilitate scalable alkaloid production
      Leonard, Effendi; Runguphan, Weerawat; O'Connor, Sarah; Prather, Kristala Jones
      Nature Chemical Biology (2009), 5 (5), 292-300CODEN: NCBABT; ISSN:1552-4450. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Numerous drugs and drug precursors in the current pharmacopoeia originate from plant sources. The limited yield of some bioactive compds. in plant tissues, however, presents a significant challenge for large-scale drug development. Metabolic engineering has facilitated the development of plant cell and tissue systems as alternative prodn. platforms that can be scaled up in a controlled environment. Nevertheless, effective metabolic engineering approaches and the predictability of genetic transformations are often obscured due to the myriad cellular complexities. Progress in systems biol. has aided the understanding of genome-wide interconnectivities in plant-based systems. In parallel, the bottom-up assembly of plant biosynthetic pathways in microorganisms demonstrated the possibilities of a new means of prodn. In this Perspective, we discuss the opportunities and challenges of implementing metabolic engineering in various platforms for the synthesis of natural and unnatural plant alkaloids.

      36
      Physostigmine (eserine). III
      Stedman, Edgar; Barger, Geo.
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Transactions (1925), 127 (), 247-58CODEN: JCHTA3; ISSN:0368-1645.
      cf. C. A. 18, 2709. Additional exptl. evidence and theoretical considerations have led to I as the formula for eseroline; physostigmine will be similar with the H of the phenolic HO replaced by MeNHCO. Reduction of eserethole by Pt black gave dihydroeserethole (II), identical with that prepd. by Polonovski (C. A. 12, 2540) using Zn and HCl; that this is a sec. base is indicated by heating with MeI in a sealed tube at 100° for 1 hr.; the product gives a dipicrate, yellow, m. 204°. Eseretholemethine-MeI and picric acid in EtOH separate an orange oil which, on warming, gives the yellow diquaternary picrate, m. 170°; in its formation H2O is eliminated from the mol., indicating the pseudo-basic function of the O atom. Oxidation of eserethole- methine by NH4OH-AgNO3 in MeOH gives dehydroeseretholemethine, isolated as the picrate, needles, m. 211°, and plates, m. 199°; from this the methiodide, m. 131° and contg. 1 H2O, was prepd. Degradation of this by Hofmann's reaction gave III, m. 62° (picrate, crimson, m. 103°), which is reduced by Pd and H to 5-ethoxy-1,3-dimethyl-3-ethyl-2-indolinone, m. 68°. HNO3 gives with eserethole a tri-NO2 deriv., orange, m. 152°. Oxidation of eserethole with KMnO4 in Me2CO at -10° for 2 days gave a red sirup, which yielded a picrate, C15H20O2N2.C6H3O7N3, m. 166°, and a methiodide, m. 198-9°. Etheserolene picrate, yellow, m. 98°. The preliminary results of the degradation of esoline Et ether di-MeI have been confirmed. The product gives a mixt. of 2 picrates, m. 156° and 159°, from which methiodides, m. 169-70° and 141°, were prepd. When the product m. 141° was heated in a sealed tube with excess of MeI, a 2nd methiodide, m. 188°, was obtained.

    37. 37
      Timoney, P. J.; Breathnach, C. S. Douglas Argyll Robertson (1837–1909) and his pupil. Ir. J. Med. Sci. 2010, 179, 119– 121,  DOI: 10.1007/s11845-009-0460-z
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      37
      Douglas Argyll Robertson (1837-1909) and his pupil
      Timoney P J; Breathnach C S
      Irish journal of medical science (2010), 179 (1), 119-21 ISSN:.
      Douglas Argyll Robertson's (1837-1909) experimental work with physostigmine in 1863 sharpened his knowledge of the innervation of the internal muscles of the eye. So he was ideally prepared in 1869 to analyse the conundrum when he saw patients with spinal cord disease who had lost the response to light even though accommodation to near objects was normal. By translating his knowledge of basic science to a clinical problem he drew attention to this phenomenon, known subsequently as the Argyll Robertson pupil that came to be considered pathognomonic of tabes dorsalis, general paresis and neurovascular syphilis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

    46. 46
      Dale, H. H. The action of certain esters and ethers of choline, and their relation to muscarine. J. Pharm. Exp. Ther. 1914, 6, 147– 190
      [CAS], Google Scholar
      46
      The action of certain esters and ethers of choline, and their relation to muscarine
      Dale, H. H.
      (1914), 6 (), 147-90 ISSN:.
      In the action of choline, and, with varying degrees of intensity, in the action of its esters (marked with acetylcholine, choline nitrous ester and choline nitric ester) and certain ethers (choline ethyl ether), 2 distinct types of action can be detected-a "muscarine" action, paralyzed by atropine, and a "nicotine" action, paralyzed by excess of nicotine. The action of choline nitrous ether is identical with "synthetic muscarine." Acetylcholine occurs occasionally in ergot, but its instability renders it improbable that its occurrence has any therapeutic significance. It appears to be hydrolyzed in the blood.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A concise synthesis of (+)-muscarine

      (+)-Muscarine iodide (I) was synthesized from S-(-)-Et lactate in five steps with the application of a zinc-mediated allylation reaction of (S)-2,6-Cl2C6H3CH2OCHMeCHO in aq. media. Reversal of chelation-control stereoselectivity was obsd. in the allylations of chiral α-alkoxy aldehydes in aq. media.

    50. 50
      Lee, M. R. The history of ergot of rye (Claviceps purpurea) II: 1900–1940. J. R. Coll. Physicians Edinb. 2009, 39, 365– 369,  DOI: 10.4997/JRCPE.2009.416
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      50
      The history of ergot of rye (Claviceps purpurea) II: 1900-1940
      Lee M R
      The journal of the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh (2009), 39 (4), 365-9 ISSN:1478-2715.
      Ergot, in 1900, was a 'chemical mess'. Henry Wellcome, the pharmaceutical manufacturer, invited Henry Hallett Dale, a physiologist, to join his research department and solve this problem. Dale, in turn, recruited an outstanding group of scientists, including George Barger, Arthur Ewins and Harold Dudley, who would make distinguished contributions not only to the chemistry of ergot but also to the identification of acetylcholine, histamine and tyramine and to studies on their physiological effects. Initially Barger and Dale isolated the compound ergotoxine, but this proved to be a false lead; it was later shown to be a mixture of three different ergot alkaloids. The major success of the Wellcome group was the discovery and isolation of ergometrine, which would prove to be life-saving in postpartum haemorrhage. In 1917 Arthur Stoll and his colleagues started work on ergot at Sandoz Pharmaceuticals in Basel. A series of important results emerged over the next 30 years, including the isolation of ergotamine in 1918, an effective treatment for migraine with aura.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3cznt1Kntg%253D%253D&md5=f5a3e590d6361a77a54f45c3d9b95c1c

      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    53. 53
      Shorter, E.; Segesser, K. Traditional Chinese Medicine and Western psychopharmacology: building bridges. Phytother. Res. 2013, 27, 1739– 1744,  DOI: 10.1002/ptr.4940
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      53
      Traditional Chinese medicine and Western psychopharmacology: building bridges
      Shorter Edward; Segesser Kathryn
      Phytotherapy research : PTR (2013), 27 (12), 1739-44 ISSN:.
      This paper demonstrates that in the treatment of psychiatric disorders, there are striking similarities between the mechanisms of psychoactive agents used in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) and those of western psychopharmacology. While western researchers search for new treatments and novel mechanisms of action, investigators in Asia are analyzing traditional remedies in order to understand the mechanisms responsible for their effectiveness. A review of contemporary pharmacologic studies of agents used in TCM for psychiatric indications reveals that virtually all of the active principles of drug action established in 20th century psychopharmacology were encountered empirically in Chinese herbal medicine over the past 2000 years. Building bridges between these two traditions may thus be of benefit to both cultures. In addition to providing western patients with a wider selection of treatment options, the effort may help Asian clinicians and researchers avoid some of the errors that have troubled their western counterparts.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3szptFKmsQ%253D%253D&md5=ac8630e41798eaa7f242c7eb288d4ce0
    54. 54
      Piness, G.; Miller, H.; Alles, G. A. Clinical observations on phenylaminoethanol sulfate. J. Am. Med. Assoc. 1930, 94, 790– 791,  DOI: 10.1001/jama.1930.02710370034010
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    55. 55
      Sitte, H. H.; Freissmuth, M. Amphetamines, new psychoactive drugs and the monoamine transporter cycle. Trends Pharmacol. Sci. 2015, 36, 41– 50,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tips.2014.11.006
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      55
      Amphetamines, new psychoactive drugs and the monoamine transporter cycle
      Sitte, Harald H.; Freissmuth, Michael
      Trends in Pharmacological Sciences (2015), 36 (1), 41-50CODEN: TPHSDY; ISSN:0165-6147. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      In monoaminergic neurons, the vesicular transporters and the plasma membrane transporters operate in a relay. Amphetamine and its congeners target this relay to elicit their actions: most amphetamines are substrates, which pervert the relay to elicit efflux of monoamines into the synaptic cleft. However, some amphetamines act as transporter inhibitors. Both compd. classes elicit profound psychostimulant effects, which render them liable to recreational abuse. Currently, a surge of new psychoactive substances occurs on a global scale. Chemists bypass drug bans by ingenuous structural variations, resulting in a rich pharmacol. A credible transport model must account for their distinct mode of action and link this to subtle differences in activity and undesired, potentially deleterious effects.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvVanug%253D%253D&md5=18de6ecc05000d320900885e41d97da2
    56. 56
      Edeleano, L. Ueber einige Derivate der Phenylmethacrylsäure und der Phenylisobuttersäure. Ber. Dtsch. Chem. Ges. 1887, 20, 616– 622,  DOI: 10.1002/cber.188702001142
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    57. 57
      Späth, E. Über dieAnhalonium-Alkaloide. Monatsh. Chem. 1919, 40, 129– 154,  DOI: 10.1007/BF01524590
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      57
      The anhalonium (cactus) alkaloids. I. Anhaline and mezcaline
      Spath, Ernst
      Monatshefte fuer Chemie (1919), 40 (), 129-54CODEN: MOCMB7; ISSN:0026-9247.
      The cactus alkaloids have been investigated most completely by Heffter (Ber. 27, 2976; 29, 223; 31, 1194; 34, 3008; 38, 3634) and 7 bases are described in the literature, namely, anhaline, mezcaline, pellotine, anhalonidine, anhalonine, anhalamine and lophophorine. These have about the same physiol. properties (Mogliewa, Arch. exp. Path. Pharm. 49, 137) and are closely related chemically. It is now shown that anhaline is identical with the hordenine of barley germs, that is, it is HOC6H4CH2CH2NMe2. Mezcaline has been synthesized by a method which shows that it is β-3,4,5-trimethoxyphenylethylamine. Anhalonine and lophophorine contain each a MeO group and 2 non-HO O atoms, but the other bases are simply methylated members of the 3,4,5-(HO)3C6H2CH2CH2NH2 series. In the synthesis of mezcaline, 3,4,5-(MeO)3C6H2CHO is prepd. by reducing 3,4,5-(MeO)3C6H2COCl in boiling PhMe by H in the presence of palladinized BaSO4, the yield being good, although some by-products are formed. The aldehyde is condensed with MeNO2 in alc. NaOH, giving Ω-nitro-3,4,5-trimethoxystyrene, C6H2(OMe)3CH:CHNO2, long yellow needles, m. 120-1°, which is then reduced with Zn dust and AcOH to an oxime and then by Na-Hg to β-3,4,5-trimethoxyphenylethylamine, highly refractive, viscous oil, b12 180-0.5°, with a faintly basic odor. The base gives the following derivs., which are identical with those obtained from a specimen of Merck's mezcaline, and already described in part by Heffter: sulfate, (C11H17NO3)2.H2SO4.2H2O, long, glistening prisms, m. 183-6°; picrate, yellow crystals, m. 216-8°; chloroplatinate, rosets of straw-yellow needles, m. 187-8°; chloraurate, with 1 H2O, orange needles, decomp. 140-1°; benzoate, m. 120-1°; m-nitrobenzoate, m. 161-2°; quaternary methiodide, C6H2-(OMe)3CH2CH2NMe3I, m. 224-5°. Heffter found on analysis that mezcaline behaves as though it contained a NHMe group, and this is confirmed. The explanation seems to be that some rearrangement in the mol. proceeds during the analysis, for Heffter himself disposed of the alternative formula, C6H2(OMe)3CH2NHMe. Still another alternative, C6H2(OMe)3CHMeNH2, is now negatived by the synthesis of the base with this formula. 3,4,5-(MeO)3C6H2COMe is converted into the oxime, needles, m. 102-3°, and this is reduced by Na-Hg. α-3,4,5-Trimethoxyphenylethylamine is a strong base which forms a solid carbonate on exposure to the air. Its benzoyl derivative, m. 150-1°, and the quaternary methiodide, m. 180-2°, then resolidifies, m. again 235-7°, and decomps. 250-5°.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaB3cXmtVWk&md5=6f61012e101319a478e581950135a256
